Nephi.desc: Nephi’s small quote of Isaiah ({1 Nephi 20–21})
Nephi’s large quote of Isaiah ({2 Nephi 12–24})
Nephi’s midrash on Isaiah 29: The sealed book ({2 Nephi 27})
Nephi speaks of words speaking from the dust ({2 Nephi 3:19–20, 27:13, 29:2})

Jacob.desc: Passage that Nephi requested Jacob to expound ({2 Nephi 6:4–18})
Jacob’s temple quotation of Isaiah ({2 Nephi 7–8})
Allusion to Isaiah by Jacob ({2 Nephi 9:50–51})

Abinadi.desc: Noah’s Priests question Abinadi about the publishers of salvation ({Mosiah 12:21–24})
Abinadi’s quote about the suffering servant ({Mosiah 14})
Abinadi teaches about the offering for sin ({Mosiah 15:10})
Abinadi gives his answer about the publishers of salvation ({Mosiah 15:14–18})

Moroni.desc: Awake, and arise from the dust ({Moroni 10:31})

Jesus.desc: Jesus describes the house of Israel’s restoration ({3 Nephi 20:30–35})
Jesus alludes to Isaiah in speaking of his work commencing, after quoting {Micah 5:8–15} ({3 Nephi 21:29})
Jesus described the expansion of the Abrahamic covenant ({3 Nephi 22})

Destruction.oref: Isaiah 32:19; Isaiah 29:2-6; Isaiah 28:17-20; Isaiah 13:4-22; Isaiah 9:18-21; Isaiah 10:5-7; Isaiah 6:11-13; Isaiah 5:8-30; Isaiah 3:1-26; Isaiah 1:7-9

A1.desc: Jehovah raises up righteousness from the east

A2.desc: Jehovah brings righteousness from the east, fulfilling his word

B1.desc: Idolatrous nations and rulers turn into dust and stubble, mountains and hills become dust and chaff

B2.desc: Idolatrous nations live in darkness and chaos  their idolatry causes weariness and exile

C1.desc: Jacob/Israel is not forsaken Israel’s Holy One regenerates and creates the wilderness

C2.desc: The Creator of heaven and earth saves Jacob/Israel

D1.desc: Idolaters are an abomination, worth nothing

D2.desc: Idolaters retire in shame and disgrace

E1.desc: Jehovah raises up ha‘iroti the Warrior figure from the sunrise

E2.desc: The Creator of heaven and earth raises up ha‘irotihu the Cyrus figure

F1.desc: Dignitaries are trodden down as mud and clay; false diviners are but wind and chaos

F2.desc: Those who dispute what Jehovah makes are but shards and clay

G1.desc: The Creator of heaven and earth creates the Servant figure, endows him with his Spirit, appoints him as a light

G2.desc: The Creator of light and peace names the Cyrus figure; Jehovah creates righteousness by implication, the Cyrus figure

H1.desc: Jehovah desolates the earth and its vegetation, dries up lakes and rivers Jehovah’s victory over his enemies

H2.desc: Jehovah dries up the deep and its rivers

I1.desc: Jehovah guides the blind by his light, levels the uneven ground

I2.desc: Jehovah creates Jacob/Israel, removes his people’s sins

J2.desc: Idolaters and their works are but chaos and ashes

K1.desc: Jacob/Israel magnifies the law and becomes illustrious because of Jehovah’s righteousness

K2.desc: Jehovah creates and succors Jacob/Israel; Jehovah poursout his Spirit and regenerates the wilderness

L1.desc: Jacob/Israel is a prey, consumed by fire for transgressing Jehovah’s law

L2.desc: Jacob/Israel’s weariness and sins bring execration

M1.desc: Jehovah creates Jacob/Israel Jehovah’s people are immune to the elements as they return from exile

M2.desc: Jehovah regenerates the wilderness through which his people travel;Jehovah creates Jacob/Israel

N1.desc: Babylon’s citizens come down as fugitives

N2.desc: Babylon’s armies of men, chariots, and horses are snuffed out

O1.desc: Jehovah, Israel’s Holy One and King, creates Israel

O2.desc: Jehovah provides a way through the Sea, a path through the mighty waters

1A.desc: [Humiliation] Babylon dethroned, disrobed, in the dust––vengeance by Israel’s God

1B.desc: [Exaltation] Zion arises from the dust, clad in robes, enthroned–the Lord’s redemption

2A.desc: [Rebirth] Israel returned to its land––strangers cleave to them

2B.desc: [Ruin] Israel in exile–oppressed by foreigners

3A.desc: [Rebirth] Israel’s authority restored––rules over its oppressors

3B.desc: [Ruin] Israel’s authority taken away––ruled by oppressors

4A.desc: [Rebirth] The Lord gives rest fron sorrow and bondage in that day

4B.desc: [Ruin] The Lord manifests his presence in that day

5A.desc: [Rebellion] Bad tidings for Babylon––her king’s reign of tyranny ends

5B.desc: [Compliance] Good tidings for Zion––her God’s reign of peace begins

6B.desc: [Compliance] The Lord returns to Zion as king

7A.desc: [Rebellion] The Tyrant struck the nationsin wrath

7B.desc: [Compliance] All nations see the Lord’s saving arm

8A.desc: [Jubilation] Jubilation––the whole earth at rest and at peace

9A.desc: [Punishment] He who hewed down Israel has gone our of her

9B.desc: [Deliverance] Those who bring back Israel’s descendants go out of Babylon

10A.desc: [Punishment] The Tyrant in the company of the dead; exiled to Sheol

10B.desc: [Deliverance] Israel returns from exile in the company of its God

11A.desc: [Humiliation] The Tyrant is demeaned, subjected to reproach

11B.desc: [Exaltation] The Servant is exalted, acquires eminence

12A.desc: [Humiliation] The ignorninious Tyrant previously enjoyed eminence

12B.desc: [Exaltation] The eminent Servant previously enjoyed ignominy

13A.desc: [Humiliation] He who subjected the nations lamented in awe

13B.desc: [Exaltation] He who purges the nations esteemed in awe

14B.desc: [Humiliation] The Servant grows up out of the earth

15A.desc: [Exaltation] The Tyrant aspires to be like the Most High

15B.desc: [Humiliation] The Servant submits to being the lowest of men

17A.desc: [Suffering] The Tyrant causes havoc and destruction

17B.desc: [Salvation] The Servant causes peace and healing

18A.desc: [Suffering] The Tyrant brings others into permanent bondage

18B.desc: [Salvation] The Servant atones for the sins of others

19A.desc: [Disloyalty] The kings of the nations die with honor

19B.desc: [Loyalty] The Servant goes like a lamb to the slaughter

20A.desc: [Disloyalty] The Tyrant is slain for his own crimes

20B.desc: [Loyalty] The Servant is slain for the crimes of his people

21A.desc: [Disloyalty] The Tyrant is unburied becausehe did violence

21B.desc: [Loyalty] The Servant is buried because he did no violence

22A.desc: [Disinheritance] The Tyrant’s offspring is slaughtered, to rise no nore

22B.desc: [Inheritance] The Servant sees his offspring perpetuated

24B.desc: [Inheritance] Zion an inheritance for the Servant and those he redeems

Narrative Characters.desc: Ephraim (the Ten–tribed Northern Kingdom of Israel)
Messengers of the King of Assyria
Joah the Son of Asaph, the Record Keeper
Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, Samaria, Hena, and Ivvah
Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and Tel Assar
Adrammelech, Sharezer, and Esarhaddon, Sons of Sennacherib

A1.desc: Prophetic Commission

A2.desc: Prophetic Commission

B1.desc: Historical Preface

B2.desc: Historical Preface

C1.desc: The King’s Rebellion

C2.desc: The King’s Compliance

Disloyalty.desc: Breaking faith with Jehovah and disobeying his law
Trusting in the arm of flesh
Taking refuge in deception and hiding behind falsehoods
Wrongly judging and turning away the righteous
Concocting schemes and working in the dark
Trusting in manipulation and double dealing

Romans.desc: {Romans 10:20} Found by those who sought me not

Corinthians.desc: {1 Corinthians 1:19} The wisdom of the wise
{2 Corinthians 6:2} Acceptable time, day of salvation
{2 Corinthians 6:17} Come out from among them

Peter.desc: {1 Peter 2:24} By his stripes you were healed
{1 Peter 3:14} Do not be in fear

OtherNewTestament.desc: {Hebrews 2:13} The children God has given me

Father\u2013Son.oref: Isaiah 1:2; Isaiah 30:1, 9; Isaiah 43:6; Isaiah 45:11; Isaiah 63:8, 16; Isaiah 64:8

Wicked Superlatives.desc: These nonetheless pass for the noble and respectable among the people
Complacent and carefree women who suffer the failure of the harvest they smugly depend on
Sinners in Zion whose common fate is to be “set ablaze” and consumed in a “devouring fire”

Righteous Superlatives.desc: Of noble intent and stand up for what is virtuous
These “wait” for Jehovah amid troubled times
They exercise “faithfulness” (’emuna) and “wisdom” (hokma) under duress and are sustained through trials by their “knowledge” (da’at) and “fear” (yir’a) of Jehovah
They exercise scrupulous integrity in a day when humanity’s integrity as the whole has broken down. They “conduct themselves righteously and are honest in word” when others do the contrary
These faithful souls survive the holocaust that consumes the godless
They live to “behold the King in his glory and view the expanse of the earth”
They obtain healing, forgiveness of sins, and abundance of spoil

Disinheritance.desc: A “hail” (barad) fells the forests and levels the wicked city
A treacherous enemy despoils and devastates the land
Highways lie desolate as travel comes to an end
The land lies withered and forlorn and turns into a dry waste
Its palatial buildings lie abandoned and become the haunt of wild animals
Although the land is that of Jehovah’s people
Its desolation attests to the false peace “humanity” (’enos) seeks in human “treaties” or “covenants” (berit)

Inheritance.desc: The righteous dwell safely in cliff fortresses in the day of burning
In their mountain retreats “bread is provided them, their water is sure”
Those who “conducted the census” and “levied the tax,” together with “the insolent people” who invaded the land, are banished forever
Those who repent/return inherit Zion, a “city of solemn assemblies,” and Jerusalem, the “abode of peace,” an “immovable tent whose stakes shall never be uprooted”
A righteous remnant of Jehovah’s people now lives “in peaceful settlements, in safe neighborhoods, in comfortable dwellings”
Their crops well watered, their animals grazing unmolested

Reversal of Circumstances.desc: The productive lands of the wicked become a desolation
But Jehovah turns the desert into productive lands for the righteous
Accompanying these reversals is a state of mourning among the wicked
But an outpouring of Jehovah’s Spirit upon the righteous
The desert or wilderness becomes a place of divine instruction for Jehovah’s people who abide there for a time:

Home, Exhile, Return.desc: Merged and become identified with the world at large
Respond to a unviersal call to repent
Upon being proven, they are part of the birth of a new nation

A descendant of David.details: A pseudonym of a descendant of David the son of Jesse, who represents Israel’s lineages that assimilated into the Gentiles as signified by the wild nature of the shoot or “watersprout”
A pseudonym of a descendant of David the son of Jesse, who represents Israel’s natural lineages that are nurtured by its assimilated lineages as signified by the grafted branch that bears fruit
A pseudonym of a descendant of David the son of Jesse, who represents the ethnic or natural lineages of Israel as signified by the primary or core nature of the tree’s stock or “trunk”

Abraham.details: A pseudonym of Abraham, Israel’s righteous progenitor, who acts as a type of Jehovah’s elect people who leave house and kindreds behind to journey to lands of inheritance Jehovah promises them

Afro\u2013Egyptian Pharaoh.details: A pseudonym of a black non–native Afro–Egyptian pharaoh of Egypt, who subjugated his people in a time of moral decline and who acts as the type of a similar ruler of an end–time “Egypt”

Covenant of Peace.details: Jehovah’s everlasting covenant of peace and salvation with his people Israel and with individuals in all its forms, manifestations, and expressions
Covenant of Peace.oref: Isaiah 24:5; Isaiah 54:10; Isaiah 55:3; Isaiah 56:4, 6; Isaiah 59:21; Isaiah 61:8

Evil End\u2013Time Servant.details: A pseudonym of an evil end–time servant, of whom Shebna is a type, who fails as a proxy savior to Jehovah’s people and whom Jehovah’s servant displaces in Jehovah’s Day of Judgment

Jehovah God of Israel.details: A creation motif and pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who personifies the greater light that lights up the earth at his coming and that diffuses through the earth in his millennial reign of peace
A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, the rock of his people’s salvation, who acts as a stronghold and sanctuary to his people who repent but as a stumbling block to those who don’t
Jehovah God of Israel.oref: Isaiah 8:14; Isaiah 17:10; Isaiah 26:4; Isaiah 30:29; Isaiah 44:8; Isaiah 48:21; Isaiah 51:1

Jehovah God of Israel.details: A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who comes to establish his reign of peace on the earth and whose presence with his elect in Zion shines like a beacon for the entire world to see
A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who exemplifies faithfulness in fulfilling his covenants and promises to his people and who establishes among them his millennial reign of peace
A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who personifies everlasting salvation to his repentant people by delivering them spiritually from their sins and temporally from their enemies
Jehovah God of Israel.oref: Isaiah 12:2-3; Isaiah 17:10; Isaiah 25:9; Isaiah 26:1, 18; Isaiah 33:2, 6; Isaiah 43:12; Isaiah 45:8, 17; Isaiah 46:13; Isaiah 49:6, 8; Isaiah 51:5-6, 8; Isaiah 52:7, 10; Isaiah 56:1; Isaiah 59:11, 16-17; Isaiah 60:18; Isaiah 61:10; Isaiah 62:1, 11; Isaiah 63:5

Jehovah God of Israel.details: A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who personifies one of two arms of God who intervene in the earth to empower his elect against the Assyrian alliance in Jehovah’s Day of Judgment
A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who resembles a sacrificial lamb during his earthly ministry, who acts as his people’s proxy savior, offering his life to atone for their transgressions
A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who reverses his people’s circumstances when they prove loyal, who endows them in the holy priesthood and empowers them against enemies
A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who typifies a sapling or stalk growing up among his apostate people but who maintains contact with the Most High God during his earthly ministry
A pseudonym of Jehovah God of Israel, who typifies a stalk or sapling growing up among his apostate people but who maintains contact with the Most High God during his earthly ministry
A pseudonym of Jehovah, who empowers his end–time servant and holy ones against the forces of evil typified by the king of Assyria/Babylon and his alliance in Jehovah’s Day of Judgment
A term signifying the presence of Jehovah, whose pillar of cloud by day and of fire by night rests on his holy ones to protect them when he comes out in judgment against the wicked of the world

Jehovah\u2019s Wife.details: A pseudonym of Jehovah’s wife, the Woman Zion, the exemplar of righteous women, who marries Jehovah by an everlasting covenant and gives birth to a righteous posterity

Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.details: A chaos motif and pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who personifies the fire that devours the Assyrian alliance when it threatens to destroy Jehovah’s elect in Jehovah’s Day of Judgment
A creation motif and pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who personifies Jehovah’s light to the nations in a time of spiritual darkness and who instructs Jehovah’s people in his law and word
Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.oref: Isaiah 2:5; Isaiah 5:20; Isaiah 9:2; Isaiah 10:17; Isaiah 42:6, 16; Isaiah 45:7; Isaiah 49:6; Isaiah 58:8, 10; Isaiah 59:9; Isaiah 60:1, 3; Isaiah 62:1

Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.details: A messianic term and pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who acts as a seraph/savior to Jehovah’s people under the terms of the Davidic Covenant in a time of peril
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant and those who vanquish the forces of chaos as they reconquer the earth for Jehovah from the power of the king of Assyria/Babylon and his alliance
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant and those who vanquish the forces of chaos as they reconquer the earth for Jehovah from the power of the king of Assyria/Babylon and his alliance
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant and those who vanquish the forces of chaos as they reconquer the earth for Jehovah from the power of the king of Assyria/Babylon and his alliance.
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant and those who vanquish the forces of chaos as they reconquer the earth for Jehovah from the power of the king of Assyria/Babylon and his alliance.
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant and those whom Jehovah empowers to speak in his name, who praise Jehovah during their wilderness journey to meet Jehovah at his coming
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, a descendant of David the son of Jesse, who represents Israel’s natural lineages as signified by the sprig that grows into a fruit–bearing branch
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, a stone or seer who receives divine revelation during a dearth of revelation and who establishes righteousness among those who believe it
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, his arm of righteousness, through whom Jehovah intervenes in the earth to restore his people and prepare them for his coming to reign on the earth
Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.oref: Isaiah 30:30; Isaiah 40:10-11; Isaiah 48:14; Isaiah 51:5, 9; Isaiah 52:10; Isaiah 53:1; Isaiah 59:16; Isaiah 62:8; Isaiah 63:5, 12

Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.details: A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, his hand of deliverance, who restores Jehovah’s people beyond their former glory and prepares the way for Jehovah’s coming to reign on the earth
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, his hand of deliverance, who saves a repentant remnant of Jehovah’s people from a worldwide destruction wrought by the king of Assyria/Babylon
Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.oref: Isaiah 1:25; Isaiah 5:12; Isaiah 11:11, 14-15; Isaiah 14:26-27; Isaiah 19:25; Isaiah 25:10; Isaiah 26:11; Isaiah 29:23; Isaiah 34:17; Isaiah 41:20; Isaiah 43:13; Isaiah 45:9, 11-12; Isaiah 48:13; Isaiah 49:2, 22; Isaiah 50:2; Isaiah 51:16, 22; Isaiah 53:10; Isaiah 59:1; Isaiah 60:21; Isaiah 62:3; Isaiah 64:8; Isaiah 65:2; Isaiah 66:2, 14

Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.details: A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, his secret weapon, who resembles a straight arrow that Jehovah empowers to slay the enemies among his own people and the wicked of the world
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, Jehovah’s mouth or mouthpiece to the world, whom Jehovah appoints to speak in his name and teach his law and word in a time of apostasy
Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.oref: Isaiah 1:20; Isaiah 11:4; Isaiah 30:2; Isaiah 34:16; Isaiah 40:5; Isaiah 45:23; Isaiah 48:3; Isaiah 49:2; Isaiah 51:16; Isaiah 55:11; Isaiah 58:14; Isaiah 59:21; Isaiah 62:2

Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.details: A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, Jehovah’s voice to his people, who receives divine revelation during a dearth of revelation and who rebukes the enemies of Jehovah’s people
Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.oref: Isaiah 24:14; Isaiah 28:23; Isaiah 29:4; Isaiah 30:19, 30-31; Isaiah 32:9; Isaiah 40:3, 6, 9; Isaiah 48:20; Isaiah 50:10; Isaiah 51:3; Isaiah 52:8; Isaiah 58:1, 4; Isaiah 66:6

Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.details: A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, of whom Eliakim is a type, who acts as a proxy savior to a remnant of Jehovah’s people in delivering them from destruction in Jehovah’s Day of Judgment
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who breathes life into Jehovah’s people at the time of their backsliding but who breathes death or punishment on Jehovah’s enemies
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who exemplifies Jehovah’s zeal for his people in restoring them beyond their former glory and preparing the way for Jehovah’s millennial reign of peace
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who exemplifies righteousness in a time of wickedness, whom Jehovah raises up from the east as a bird of prey against his enemies
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who instructs Jehovah’s people in the law of Jehovah’s covenant in a time of apostasy and who pronounces covenant curses on Jehovah’s enemies
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who manifests Jehovah’s rage toward the king of Assyria/Babylon and his alliance for their excesses in committing worldwide genocide
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who musters a remnant of Jehovah’s people to his standard and qualifies them for deliverance from destruction in Jehovah’s Day of Judgment
A pseudonym of Jehovah’s end–time servant, who personifies Jehovah’s covenant and who acts as its mediator to God’s people as did Moses
Jehovah\u2019s End\u2013Time Servant.oref: Isaiah 42:6; Isaiah 49:8; Isaiah 54:10; Isaiah 55:3; Isaiah 56:4, 6; Isaiah 59:21; Isaiah 61:8

Rebirth\u2014National.desc: Zion—a spiritual and political center for peoples of all nations additionally possesses a national dimension: Zion becomes a “city of righteousness”, a place where Jehovah’s cloud of glory rests to protect his people
Jehovah’s ransomed ones, on the other hand, return to Zion, crowned with everlasting joy
Wilderness and desert blossom as the crocus
The thirsty place becomes springs of water
Jehovah’s holy ones once again traverse highways and roads

Rebirth\u2014Universal.desc: The nations of the world, on the other hand, participate in Zion’s rebirth when it gains universal prominence
Jehovah’s law and word go forth from Zion and from Jerusalem to many peoples
Jehovah’s plant grows resplendent and renowned, and the earth’s fruit becomes the pride and glory of Israel’s survivors
Its inhabitants, those whom Jehovah ransoms and redeems, hail from unnamed origins, presumably universal

Ruin\u2014National.desc: The rulers of Jehovah’s people pursue payoffs and personal rewards
Their elders enrich themselves by depriving the needy
Their leaders mislead them, abolishing their traditional ways
Jerusalem and Judea suffer a dearth of food and leadership, causing anarchy and collapse
The women of Jehovah’s people are stripped of their finery
The land’s gateways lie bereaved and forlorn, lacking traffic
Like a widow in mourning, Jehovah’s people sit on the ground, destitute
Aliens have invaded the land and laid it waste
The mountains quake and the people’s corpses lie like litter about the streets
Lebanon and Bashan, mountains and hills, towers and ships are laid low
The land lies ruined, its cities burned with fire
Jehovah’s “vineyard” has turned into a desolation, overgrown by briars and thorns
Exception: he ruin of “all nations” (kol haggoyim) is characterized as the ruin of “Edom,” a national entity
The people of Edom—descendants of Esau who sold his birthright for a mess of pottage (cf. {Genesis 25:29–34})—here epitomize all peoples who show enmity toward Zion

Ruin\u2014Universal.desc: Exception: Jehovah’s condemnation of his alienated people Israel occurs synonymously or concurrently with his condemnation of the nations: Jehovah “has arisen to judge the nations”
Exception: the “mountains” quaking at Jehovah’s anger may be read allegorically as “kingdoms” or “nations” quaking
The earth and the world should take warning
Jehovah’s rage is upon all nations, whom he has doomed, consigned to the slaughter
When the heavens roll up as a scroll, its starry hosts cast themselves down
The earth turns into a wasteland

A2.desc: Bozrah/Edom

B2.desc: Beasts of Edom

Ruin.desc: [Unit 1] The diseased condition of the entire body of Israel
[Unit 1] The devastation of the land by fire and by enemies
[Unit 1] The overthrow and desolation of dwelling places
[Unit 1] Israel’s destruction almost as Sodom
[Unit 1] Natural calamities
[Unit 1] The annihilation of those who forsake Jehovah
[Unit 1] Corpses lying about unburied
[Unit 1] A lack of food and clothing
[Unit 1] The cutting off of offspring
[Unit 1] The infertility and poor yield of the land
[Unit 1] A lack of moisture and the overgrowing of the land by briars and thorns
[Unit 1] The abandonment of the land
[Unit 1] And light turned to darkness
[Unit 1] Ruin, in the first unit, culminates at Jehovah’s appearance within the same context of a “Day of Jehovah” (yom layhwh)—Jehovah’s Day of Judgment.
[Unit 1] Then takes place a final, maledictory abasement of all who exalt themselves against him
[Unit 2] The slaughter of men and “all nations” (kol haggoyim)
[Unit 2] Cataclysmic destruction
[Unit 2] Unburied corpses
[Unit 2] Infertility of the earth
[Unit 2] The earth’s turning into lava, brimstone, and pitch
[Unit 2] A wasteland forever
[Unit 2] A haunt of wild animals and birds of prey
[Unit 2] As in the first unit, ruin takes the form of covenantal malediction within the context of a “Day of Jehovah” (yom . . . layhwh)—Jehovah’s Day of Judgment (see 2:12)
[Unit 2] Ruin culminates with the cessation of Edom as a political entity denoting the political demise of the nations of the Gentiles,

Rebirth.desc: [Unit 1] Zion as those of Jehovah’s people who “repent” (swb) of transgression.
[Unit 1] A similar parallelistic denomination of Zion
[Unit 1] A restoration of political power
[Unit 1] The mountain of Jehovah’s house in the “last days” or “end–time” (’aharit hayyamim) established as21 the “head of the mountains” (ro’s heharim)
[Unit 1] Jehovah restores his law and word
[Unit 1] Zion will assume its rightful place as head of the nations. When that event takes place, the nations experience an unprecedented era of peace
[Unit 1] Israel’s rebirth as Zion, which consists of a reversal of malediction, culminates with the flowering of a righteous remnant of Jehovah’s people at the time Jehovah regenerates the earth
[Unit 1] Meanwhile, a cloud of glory forms a protective canopy over the assemblies of Zion during Jehovah’s Day of Judgment

[Unit 1] We thus distinguish between those whom Jehovah ransoms from ruin—a category of his people that experiences rebirth—and those whose ruin is identical with the demise of reprobates, who nonetheless comprise his people
[Unit 1] The juxtaposition of these verses with Zion’s ransoming and restoration  shows that the ruin of Jehovah’s enemies and the rebirth of Zion occur concurrently
[Unit 1] Just as the structure of Part I implies
[Unit 2] Rebirth in the second unit occurs when Jehovah reverses covenantal malediction for those who are identified as “holy” (qds)—who traverse the “Way of Holiness”
[Unit 2] Jehovah restores his glory to the land
[Unit 2] Moisture comes to the wilderness
[Unit 2] The wilderness turns fertile
[Unit 2] The feeble receive strength
[Unit 2] The blind, deaf, dumb, and lame receive healing
[Unit 2] The wicked and beasts of prey depart the land
[Unit 2] And joy and singing break out
[Unit 2] Rebirth culminates at Jehovah’s appearance, when Jehovah delivers and rewards those who hold out faithful to him.
[Unit 2] Within that context of rebirth, Zion forms the abode of Jehovah’s “ransomed” ones (pdh), those who “repent/return” (swb)

Zion.desc: Part I thus establishes Zion as both a people and a place—those of Jehovah’s people who repent of transgression and the place to which they return from among the nations

Avenge\/Reward.desc: Jehovah comes simultaneously “to avenge and to reward”

His glory rests on nascent Zion to protect his holy people from harmful elements—from the “storm” (zerem) and “burning” (ba‘er) that overtake the world—but also to regenerate them in the blossoming wilderness
Jehovah’s retribution on wicked entities in his day of vengeance, while Jehovah’s righteous people are delivered from these same elements

Structurally as well as contextually, therefore, Jehovah’s “day of vengeance” (yom naqam) upon his alienated people and the nations is at the same time “the year of retribution on behalf of Zion” (senat sillumim lerib siyyon) cf. 1:27–28; 63:4

1B.desc: Slaughter of Edom and the nations by a sword and the nations’ corpses lying unburied

4B.desc: Cessation of travel in Edom’s land  and its overgrowing by briars and thorns

Rebellion\u2014Ahaz.desc: Ahaz rebels against Jehovah when he rejects Jehovah’s assurance to protect him and his people against a military invasion by Aram (Syria) and Ephraim (the ten–tribed Northern Kingdom of Israel)

Isaiah’s play on words to Ahaz, “If you do not believe it, it is because you are not loyal to him” (’im lo’ ta’aminu ki lo’ te’amenu) (), expresses Ahaz’s rebellion. As the historical background of that encounter shows, Ahaz spurns Jehovah’s protection in favor of protection by the king of Assyria.
Rebellion\u2014Ahaz.details: By appealing to Tiglath–Pileser king of Assyria for help against Aram and Ephraim, calling himself his “servant” and “son” ({2 Kings 16:7}), Ahaz repudiates Jehovah’s lordship and makes himself the king of Assyria’s vassal.

Rebellion\u2014Ahaz.desc: In response, Isaiah predicts that Assyria itself will invade the land

Ahaz should know that Jehovah’s guarantee of a continuing Davidic dynasty (cf. {Psalm 132:11}) will prevent Aram and Ephraim from overthrowing Ahaz and forcing Judah to join their alliance against Assyria
The terms “shaken” and “intimidated”, however, betray Ahaz’s distrust of Jehovah’s protection against the Syro–Ephraimite threat.
Isaiah’s counsel to remain “calm” and “unafraid”—which terms reflect reliance on Jehovah—underscores Jehovah’s faithfulness to the Davidic Covenant and its protection clause.
Ahaz caps his rebellion by self–righteously declining the sign Isaiah offers that will confirm Jehovah’s willingness to protect him and his people
The presence of Isaiah’s son “Shear–Jashub” (“A remnant will repent/return,”) at the encounter with Ahaz presages Jehovah’s judgment of his people in the event the king proves disloyal.
Rebellion\u2014Ahaz.details: . At the same time, the son’s name denotes that Jehovah will make provision for a repentant remnant of his people to survive destruction according to the terms of his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (cf. {Genesis 22:17; Exodus 2:24}).

Rebellion\u2014Ahaz.desc: Covenant curses—represented by a plague of flies and bees, captivity, and the land’s overgrowth by briars and thorns—betoken Jehovah’s imminent judgment.

Rebellion\u2014People.desc: [South] The people preoccupy themselves with political rather than spiritual realities
Rebellion\u2014People.details: They reject the unfailing Waters of Shiloah, symbol of the Davidic dynasty, endorsing, instead, the fractious Syro–Ephraimite coalition against Assyria

Rebellion\u2014People.desc: [South] They live in dread of conspiracy and don’t seek refuge in Jehovah
[South] They scorn Jehovah by inquiring of mediums and spiritists for doctrine and for a testimony
[South] Consequently, Jehovah hides his face from them
[South] He determines to curse them with military reversals, captivity, famine, and deprivation.
[North] The Northrn Kingdom seeks to replace Ahaz with a non–Davidic puppet ruler, the son of Tabeal
[North] That political course, which finds support in Judah, contravenes Jehovah’s unconditional promise to David of an unbroken dynasty
[North] Jehovah thus esteems the two houses of Israel as one and sends both, equally, the maledictory portent of Isaiah’s other son, “Maher–Shalal–Hash–Baz” (“Hasten the plunder, hurry the spoil,”)
[North] Isaiah predicts that the king of Assyria will swarm over the land and strip it bare
[North] In the likeness of Lord Nahar—the mythological god River, a power of chaos—the king of Assyria will “overflow all his banks,” “sweep into Judea like a flood,” and “reach the neck”
Rebellion\u2014People.details: The neck, however, leaves the head, the capital city (Jerusalem), implying that Jehovah will provide for the deliverance of a remnant.

Compliance\u2014Hezekiah.desc: The Assyrian general Rabshakeh and his army take up a position at the very place where Isaiah had challenged Ahaz
On pain of death, he rejects the king of Assyria’s proposal for him and his people to surrender and be transplanted to another part of the Assyrian empire
He repudiates the king of Assyria’s lordship in favor of Jehovah’s
He relies on Jehovah to come to his aid at Assyria’s siege of the city
Hezekiah’s loyalty merits Jehovah’s renewed protection
Jehovah delivers a remnant of his people by sending his angel, who destroys the invading Assyrian host in one night
Hezekiah caps his covenantal compliance by accepting Jehovah’s will unreservedly when he falls mortally ill
Jehovah, in turn, shows his approval of Hezekiah by giving him a sign vouchsafing his recovery
Hezekiah’s fidelity toward Jehovah in each instance results in Jehovah’s promise to protect his people against Assyria

Compliance\u2014People.desc: The political condition then prevailing in the Near East greatly favored Assyria
Not only had Damascus (Syria), Samaria (the Northern Kingdom of Israel), and the greater part of Judea by this time fallen prey to Assyria’s ambitions, so had many nations of the ancient world
The Assyrian general asserts that Hezekiah’s loyalty toward Jehovah will prove his people’s destruction
However, people and their representatives stand their ground, following strictly the king’s command.
The people’s covenantal compliance is linked to Hezekiah’s own compliance
Compliance\u2014People.details: Their common loyalty suggests that political and spiritual accord exists between king and people.

Cumulative Themes I \u2013 II.desc: [Nat’l Ruin] The Northern and Southern Kingdoms—are to suffer Jehovah’s judgments at the hands of Assyria, together with Aram, the nations of the world, and distant lands.
[Rebirth] “A man” (’is) who will keep alive a young cow and a pair of sheep
[Rebirth] “My disciples” (limmuday), who cleave to Jehovah’s “law” (tora) and “testimony” (te‘uda)
[Rebirth] “Me and the children Jehovah has given me”
[Rebirth] Jehovah, who “dwells in Mount Zion”, constitutes a “sanctuary” (miqdas), a refuge in troubled times to those who fear him.
[Rebirth] Isaiah expresses the safety faithful individuals find in Jehovah in the midst of widespread alienation.
[Univ. Ruin] Nations of the world suffer destruction along with Samaria and all the fortified cities of Judea, fulfilling Isaiah’s prediction in the first
[Nat’l Ruin] A “remnant” (se’erit/peleta) of Jehovah’s people, which takes refuge in Jerusalem, survives Assyria’s assault.

[Univ. Ruin] In that saving context—of Jehovah’s deliverance of a remnant from destruction—those who survive are called “the Virgin Daughter of Zion” (betulat bat–siyyon), who laughs the Assyrian king to scorn; and “the Daughter of Jerusalem” (bat yerusalayim), who shakes her head at him ().
[Nat’l Ruin] Those whom Jehovah ruins, who suffer destruction, are people who covenantally alienate themselves at a test of their loyalty.
[Nat’l Ruin] To them Jehovah is a “stumbling block” and a “snare catching [them] unawares”, leaving them unprepared for the evil time.

[Nat’l Ruin] Those who experience rebirth, on the other hand, survive destruction when they demonstrate covenantal compliance at a similar test of their loyalty. Once having passed Jehovah’s test by remaining faithful through a life–or–death situation, they are known by the names “Zion” and “Jerusalem”.
[Ruin] Assyria’s destruction of Jehovah’s alienated people and the nations
Cumulative Themes I \u2013 II.details: Represented in both units of Part II

Cumulative Themes I \u2013 II.desc: [Rebirth] Zion’s rebirth appears implicitly in the first unit
[Rebirth] Zion’s rebirth flowers in the second unit
A single test of loyalty—in a day when Jehovah’s appearance draws near—evokes two opposite responses from Jehovah’s people and their rulers

Watchmen\/Prophets.desc: End–time servant as a watchman for the Lord’s people

0.desc: Watchmen who see, hear, and report

1.desc: Watchmen who are blind and unaware

(1\/7) Perdition.desc: The king figure refers to an end–time archtyrant whom God sends against his covenant people to punish them for their wickedness in a time of apostasy.

In the pattern of ancient Assyrian world conquerors, the end–time “king of Assyria” invades all lands, conquers a corrupt world, and boasts of his exploits without acknowledging God as the one who empowers him.
The king of Assyria conquers even the great world superpower Egypt and sets his sights on a righteous remnant of God’s people, claiming he will make short work of them also.

Like the ancient gods of myth, he ascends to what appears to be a space station, from which he rules the earth. But even from there he is cast down, his spirit condemned to the Pit of Dissolution, there to suffer for his genocidal crimes against humanity.
As the exemplar of oppressors and evildoers, the king of Assyria joins other world tyrants in hell, a place the wicked cannot escape
The spirits of the wicked in that place serve as a reminder to all humanity of the consequences of defying God
Unlike persons who repent of doing evil, Perdition types never rise above their damned state. Even the memory of them ultimately vanishes with them.

(2\/7) Babylon\u2013Chaldea.desc: End–time Babylon is the earth, the world, sinners, and the wicked on the eve of their destruction
Babylon is a harlot who seeks to displace God by appropriating his godhood to herself.
End–time Babylon’s self–exaltation comes to an end when Israel’s God reverses the circumstances of Zion and Babylon, exalting the one from the dust to her throne
Humiliating the other from her throne into the dust
He appoints a “watchman”—a prophet or seer— inferring that other watchmen don’t report what they see, or don’t see at all.
Babylon’s “fall” compares with that of Sodom and Gomorrah—it never rises up again
Babylon’s inhabitants include in their ranks those who were God’s people but who corrupt themselves and apostatize

These wicked include the leaders of God’s people who decry the new things God does at the end of the world and who disparage his seer—his end–time servant—colluding instead with the political establishment and relying on an arm of flesh
God’s end–time servant and his associates warn those who repent of evil to flee Babylon—to escape into the wilderness and not fall victim to its imminent desolation
The exodus of God’s elect out of Greater Babylon into the wilderness resembles Israel’s ancient exodus out of Egypt and God’s victory over the armies of Pharaoh.
Those who remain behind in Babylon partake of its curses when Babylon’s time runs out
Only Zion and persons affiliated with Zion live on into the earth’s millennial age of peace.

(3\/7) Jacob\u2013Israel.desc: Although they believe in the God of Israel and practice a form of religion, people in the Jacob/Israel category become lax in their devotions and blame him for their misfortunes instead of repenting of their sins.

The Jacob/Israel category loves its idols—things of men’s own making—more than its God. The result is a spiritual blindness to the truths of God that guard his people against enemies at home and abroad without their even being aware of their fallen state.
Israel’s God appoints his end–time servant to persuade his people to awaken from their spiritual inertia and save their souls.
His task is free God’s people from bondage to sin and from subjugation to enemies.
The servant’s task is to deliver them from their self–righteousness and to exemplify God’s righteousness to them.
So steeped are God’s people in their materialistic idolatry that at times God’s servant feels as though he has “labored in vain”.

While most people today see the ludicrousness of bowing down before manmade statues as their ancestors did, they nevertheless fail to see how close a resemblance that ancient practice still has to the worship of idols in the modern age.
Only a few of the Jacob/Israel category ultimately respond to God’s servant by repenting of evildoing. Instead, a majority prefers a course fraught with covenant curses.
In their pride, the descendants of Ephraim come under special condemnation.

God’s destruction of the wicked leaves only a small remnant of the Jacob/Israel category—those for whom God’s Day of Judgment serves as a time to repent. That repentance, though belated, nevertheless assures their survival.
Last–minute appeals to the Jacob/Israel category may yield the salvation of a few souls.
Disposing of the idols is the first step.

(4\/7) Zion\u2013Jerusalem.desc: Beginning with the Jacob/Israel category, persons who prove loyal through the time of testing that God orchestrates succeed in ascending to higher spiritual levels.

If they abandon their idols and return wholeheartedly to him—they are assured God’s holy Spirit will guide them as Jehovah’s coming to the earth draws near, that they will live to enjoy blessed lands of inheritance.
God’s people to whom Jehovah comes—consists of those of Jacob/Israel who repent of transgression.
At his coming, Jehovah fights their battles and delivers them from enemies too powerful for them.
Before he reverses their circumstances in his Day of Judgment, however, Jehovah tests his people’s loyalties.
With Jehovah as its God, Zion/Jerusalem repudiates false suitors such as the king of Assyria.
Zion/Jerusalem’s watchmen intercede with Israel’s God to restore his people to the glory he had promised them.
With Jehovah as her husband, Zion brings forth a nation of her children.
God’s people receive a new commission to minister to those who have yet to ascend to their level.
At Jehovah’s coming to dwell with his people, a new era of peace begins on the earth.

(5\/7) Sons\u2013Servants.desc: When a large Assyrian army surrounds Jerusalem—where a remnant of God’s people loyal to King Hezekiah has taken refuge—the king appeals to Jehovah his God for his people’s protection.
A repentant remnant of God’s people under a mortal threat from enemies looks to their king—their Messiah—for deliverance, while their king looks to his God.
Hezekiah’s responsibility is to intercede with Israel’s God on their behalf. For his intercession to be effectual, however, his loyalty must be impeccable.

On the model of ancient Near Eastern emperor–vassal covenants, the king is answerable for his people’s disloyalties to their God if he is to obtain his people’s physical protection. In that case, there could be a heavy price to pay.
Hezekiah writes, recounting the event of his personal mortal threat from his illness.
Lending substance to his intercession with Jehovah, the king’s suffering satisfies the requirements of justice for his people’s disloyalties to their God and Jehovah accepts the king’s petition.
He sends his angel, who slays the besieging Assyrian army in one night.

In the pattern of King Hezekiah, end–time persons who ascend to the son/servant level similarly function as proxy saviors of those to whom they minister under the terms of the Davidic Covenant. For their intercession with Israel’s God to be effectual, however, their loyalty to him must likewise be impeccable, even in the face of severe opposition.
Though enemies threaten, God’s sons/servants’ faith in the protection clause of the Davidic Covenant that is based on their righteousness guarantees God’s deliverance.

The “sons” and “daughters” whom Israel’s God thus re–creates on the son/servant level—those “formed,” “molded,” and “wrought” for his glory—he brings home to lands of inheritance in an end–time exodus from the four parts of the earth.
So numerous are Israel’s returnees that the Woman Zion is astonished at the multitude of her long–lost children.
Even as Jehovah’s current, unfaithful wife is cast off, his formerly unfaithful wife—she who was cast off but who has repented—he remarries.

(6\/7) Seraphs\u2013Seraphim.desc: God’s end–time servant exemplifies one whom Israel’s God exalts on the seraph level. His descent into suffering and humiliation—as he fulfills the role of a proxy savior to God’s people under the terms of the Davidic Covenant—includes being ecclesiastically ostracized and physically disfigured by enemies.

The “kings” mentioned in these passages—unlike the political kings of the nations, whom God condemns—are persons who hear God’s servant and similarly serve as proxy saviors to God’s people on the seraph level under the terms of the Davidic Covenant.
(6\/7) Seraphs\u2013Seraphim.oref: Isaiah 1:23-24; Isaiah 3:14; Isaiah 24:21-22; Isaiah 30:33; Isaiah 41:2; Isaiah 45:1

(6\/7) Seraphs\u2013Seraphim.desc: These are kings and their queens who ascend from the son/servant category as they fulfill the greater task of restoring God’s exiled people to lands of inheritance.

In contrast to the blind and dumb watchmen who occupy the highest echelon of society—whom God reprimands and gives over to covenant curses—they rise from the lowest echelon to become fellowservants of God’s end–time servant.
Isaiah uses the historical example of “foreigners” and “eunuchs” to make his point.

Such an “everlasting name” signifies an unconditional covenant that God makes with those who prove faithful under all conditions. Isaiah, creates a composite of personas to depict God’s end–time servants. This composite category are (1) a general class of end–time “servants” of God—as distinct from and on a higher spiritual level than those in the son/servant category; (2) new “watchmen” who displace the old blind and deaf watchmen; (3) “priests” of God; and (4) “kings” of his people.

Like God’s end–time servant, his fellowservants receive opposition from their own people as an integral part of their descent phase through trials and affliction while fulfilling the role of proxy saviors under the terms of the Davidic Covenant. In the end, however—after they prove faithful under all conditions—God reverses their circumstances and empowers them over their enemies.
Moses stretch forth his arm at Israel’s exodus out of Egypt as the pseudonym of God’s arm.
God empowers his end–time servant as the time draws near for his dispersed people to return home in a new exodus to Zion.
God’s empowering his arm is synonymous with his “baring” or “revealing” his arm and commissioning his servant and his fellowservants to herald Jehovah’s imminent coming.
Relying solely upon Jehovah to the exclusion of all else, they “ascend” to become unwearying—like Jehovah himself.
God delivers many of his people at the time he destroys the wicked of the world.

(7\/7) Jehovah God of Israel.desc: Jehovah takes upon himself God’s people’s sins and transgressions. He willingly fulfills the requirements of justice by suffering the curses of the covenant that have accrued to his people who repent of transgression, obviating the need for them to answer for them.
Persons who perceive the magnitude of Jehovah’s sacrifice on behalf of his people can’t help but exude gratitude for such infinite love.
From Jehovah’s foundational sacrifice for sin springs all salvation, spiritual and temporal.
Jehovah’s coming to establish his reign of peace on the earth nevertheless has a twofold aspect, additionally involving the demise of those who don’t repent.
Once his people prove loyal as a nation by keeping his law and word, Israel’s God reverses their circumstances and restores them to glory.
Upon their adverse circumstances being reversed, God’s people enter an entirely new phase of human existence.

Israel\u2019s Apostasy.desc: When God’s people as a whole had become spiritually corrupt—he uses that historical precedent as the type or pattern of an end–time corruption, showing how their drifting into a condition of spiritual atrophy over two generations ends in outright apostasy.
The people’s biggest problem, ancient and end–time, is their idolatry—their infatuation with the things of this world.
Israel\u2019s Apostasy.oref: Isaiah 2:7-8; Isaiah 2:20; Isaiah 17:7-8; Isaiah 27:9; Isaiah 30:22; Isaiah 31:7; Isaiah 44:15; Isaiah 48:4-5

Israel\u2019s Apostasy.desc: As it grows widespread, this preoccupation with material things generates spiritual blindness, an inability by God’s people to discern the new reality—that their religion has morphed from what God had revealed—that it has made a fundamental shift into a belief system that displaces the power of God with the precepts of men, thereby failing to fulfill people’s spiritual needs. Of this generational backsliding, the people and their leaders are thus entirely unaware.
A kind of delusion sets in among ecclesiastical leader as the people subscribe to the new narrative that merely perpetuates the status quo.
When a spirit of self–sufficiency follows the people’s prosperity, spiritual standards grow lax and predatory practices prevail.
God responds by calling his people to account, subjecting them to the curses of his covenant instead of pouring out his blessings.

The Tower of Babel.desc: The earth’s wayward inhabitants—those who follow the vain imaginations of their hearts in the modern world—God destroys in his Day of Judgment.

The Babylonian Captivity.desc: To the Harlot Babylon—who represents an idolatrous materialistic world empire in the Book of Isaiah—Jehovah says he her gave Israel.
Historically, the Babylonian captivity is the third occasion God’s people become subject to a foreign world power.

The Call of Abraham.desc: Jehovah reminds them that what he did for Abraham he will do for them if they heed his call. As Abraham came from the ends of the earth and received a Promised Land, so would they.
Isaiah nevertheless sees that only persons who are righteous as Abraham heed Jehovah’s call.
As with Abraham, the lands of inheritance and blessed offspring God promises his elect are theirs by an “everlasting covenant”.

Lot\u2019s Deliverance from Sodom.desc: In the end–time version of these events, when wickedness peaks to the degree it did in Sodom and Gomorrah, God again rescues his elect while many others of his people perish for corrupting their lives.

Just as Abraham acted as a proxy savior to Lot when God destroyed the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah, so God’s end–time servants act as proxy saviors to those whom God delivers from an end–time Sodom and Gomorrah type of destruction.

The Destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah.desc: Jehovah’s calling his own people by the names Sodom and Gomorrah indicates they have become as ungodly as those cities’ ancient inhabitants. Therefore they must suffer the same fate.
Even though God delivers a righteous few among his end–time people as he did Lot and his daughters from Sodom and Gomorrah, many end up perishing in the inferno.
Because such wickedness by God’s end–time people is the catalyst of a worldwide Sodom and Gomorrah type of desolation, they experience what Babylon does.

Cosmic Disturbance.desc: Isaiah predicts similar end–time instances of cosmic upheaval as an integral part of God’s cleansing of the earth of its wicked inhabitants.
Cosmic Disturbance.oref: Isaiah 24:18-20; Isaiah 51:6; Isaiah 50:3; Isaiah 13:9-10, 13; Isaiah 2:21; Isaiah 34:2-5

Primordial Chaos.desc: Isaiah’s portrayal of the earth’s creation best depicts God’s organization of the basic elements of “dust” and “waters” from their preexistent state into a place fit for human habitation.
God’s end–time de–creation of chaotic entities as he reduces the wicked of his people and the nations to nothing or non–entities: Dust.

Assyria\u2019s World Conquest.desc: According to the way Isaiah nuances Assyria’s world conquest, the mastermind of that grand exploit is its tyrannical king, whom Jehovah appoints to that task on the heels of the apostasy of Jehovah’s own people.
An evil alliance of nations rallies to Assyria’s standard to accomplish the job of conquering the world.
Because of his remarkable success, the Assyrian archtyrant attributes all to his own genius, not to Israel’s God who empowers him.
After he serves Jehovah’s purpose of punishing a wicked world, the Assyrian boaster himself comes to an end.
Passing himself off as the god of this world, the archtyrant’s self–exaltation finally leads to his utter humiliation.

The Flood.desc: By comparing the Assyrian archtyrant and his alliance of nations to the sea in commotion and to a river in flood, Isaiah draws on ancient Near Eastern mythology to tell us that the new Flood is as devastating as the old and serves the same purpose. Beginning with his own people, Jehovah permits the powers of chaos to predominate until the earth is cleansed of wickedness.
When the new Flood has served its purpose, Jehovah relents and receives back his people who repent.
Assyria and its alliance meet the same fate they impose on the world they destroy and subjugate.

Assyria\u2019s Invasion of the Promised.desc: Jehovah’s own people, have sunk into a lax and licentious state. In contrast, the Assyrian alliance is well–disciplined.
Assyria\u2019s Invasion of the Promised.oref: Isaiah 8:15; Isaiah 28:12-13; Isaiah 29:10; Isaiah 43:22; Isaiah 50:4; Isaiah 59:10; Isaiah 5:26-29

Assyria\u2019s Invasion of the Promised.desc: The king of Assyria’s unstoppable military machine advances into country after country, his ultimate goal being the conquest of God’s elect.
Assyria’s armies are defeated in two major battles in the end.

The Egyptian Bondage.desc: Although the end–time versions of ancient events are much briefer in duration—all being compressed into a period of just a few years—their reality matches what occurred in the past.
God releases from bondage those of his people who repent, after the curse serves its purpose of restoring them to a covenant relationship with him.
Jehovah’s servant, who is elsewhere called “the angel of his presence”, was directly involved in delivering Israel in Moses’ day.

Israel\u2019s Exodus out of Egypt.desc: He raises up and empowers his end–time servant—his mighty arm—to deliver his people at the end of the world.
Israel’s end–time exodus, instead of being from a single land—Egypt—is out of Babylon, which Isaiah identifies as the world at large on the eve of its destruction.
At the new exodus, the name “Babylon” thus functions as a codename of the world in its corrupt state.
Just as the angel of Jehovah accompanies Israel’s ancient exodus, so on this occasion Jehovah himself accompanies them.
Exiting end–time Babylon, God’s people thus arrive from the four corners of the earth.
As before, no armies or elements stand in their way.

Israel\u2019s Wandering in the Wildernes.desc: Isaiah predicts that God appoints his end–time servant to lead the new exodus and new wandering in the wilderness just as Moses does in antiquity.
Not only does God provide water in the wilderness for his people as before, he also regenerates the wilderness so that its trees provide shade.
The new wandering in the wilderness has a way of leveling the playing field for God’s end–time people as they anticipate Jehovah’s coming to reign on the earth.
God’s repentant people who survive the earth’s cleansing to inherit the Promised Land receive instruction in the wilderness, just as the Israelites do anciently.

Israel\u2019s Pilgrimage to Zion.desc: In the end–time version of these events, when the rest of the world is suffering God’s judgments, those who love Jehovah rejoice in taking part in the great gathering to his temple.

Many descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob assimilate into the nations of the Gentiles, many who return from dispersion in the end–time exodus and wandering in the wilderness reclaim their Israelite identity and renew their covenant with Jehovah.
Kings and their queens assist Israel’s scattered remnants to return from dispersion.

Jehovah\u2019s Protective Cloud.desc: Jehovah’s cloud shields his end–time elect from their enemies as in the past, and provides them with light during a time of darkness.
In the midst of enemy assaults, God’s cloud of glory protects his elect people from harm.
And as the angel of God accompanied his people in the past, so Jehovah accompanies their end–time travels.

Assyria\u2019s Siege of Jerusalem.desc: Assyria’s siege of Jerusalem in Isaiah’s day set another historical precedent that typifies an end–time such event by an end–time Assyria.
While demanding the city’s surrender on pain of death, the military commander vilifies King Hezekiah and attempts to win the people over.
The king of Assyria himself follows the same tactic.
The people prove loyal to their king and the king proves loyal to God, Jehovah answers Hezekiah through the prophet Isaiah.
Hezekiah suffers a mortal illness to pay the price of his people’s deliverance.
As Hezekiah pays the price of his people’s deliverance by his mortal illness, so does God’s servant when he is “marred beyond human likeness” by his enemies.
Having passed God’s test of their loyalty, King Hezekiah and his people ascend to the next highest spiritual level.

The Passover.desc: Isaiah predicts an end–time Passover in which those who rely of Jehovah’s proxy salvation escape his wrath upon a wicked world.
Isaiah depicts Jehovah as “a lamb led to slaughter” in the course of fulfilling his role as a proxy savior of his people.
Jehovah himself becomes “an offering for guilt".
No further Passover Lamb is needed to symbolize his atonement for transgression after Jehovah becomes “an offering for guilt".
In the earth’s millennial age, any animal sacrifice will be an abhorrence.

Jehovah\u2019s Descent on the Mount.desc: In the end–time version of these events, the enemies of God’s people are the ones who quail and quake before him, though these may include the evildoers of his own people.
Jehovah’s appearance to the elders of his people on Mount Sinai has a sequel in his end–time appearance to his elders at the time he comes to reign on the earth.

Jehovah\u2019s Consuming Fire.desc: When Jehovah’s end–time coming to the earth draws near, his fire burns up both the offenders among his own people and his people’s enemies alike.
Jehovah’s agent for burning up the wicked of his people and the nations is the king of Assyria and his alliance, who personify the fire that consumes them.
The very fate the king of Assyria brought upon others, however, he himself suffers when Jehovah makes an end of him.

Israel\u2019s Conquest of the Promised L.desc: Isaiah predicts that at the time Israel’s end–time tribes gather from the four directions of the earth.
Judah and Ephraim unite to conquer their enemies.
In that day, Jehovah again fights for them as he did in the past.
God’s people whom the tyrannical king of Assyria takes captive, too, are freed from his power.
As the millennial age dawns, God’s people spread throughout the earth.

Israel\u2019s Victory over Midian.desc: Isaiah predicts similar such miraculous victories over an Assyrian alliance that threatens God’s end–time people in which Jehovah’s servant plays the role of Gideon.

Cyrus\u2019 Universal Conquests.desc: Isaiah’s Seven–Part Structure identifies those territories as an integral part of Greater Babylon—a conglomerate of nations under Babylon’s influence comparable to John’s Babylon the Great.
Under the pseudonym of Jehovah’s Righteousness—alluding to Abraham, who was a model of righteousness—God’s servant, too, conquers all the kingdoms of the earth.
Isaiah mention Cyrus by name in two instances that follow.

The two historical precedents in whose connection Isaiah cites the name of Cyrus are (1) of a world conqueror empowered by God who releases God’s people from captivity in Babylon and (2) of one who commands the rebuilding of Jerusalem and its temple.
In one instance, Isaiah combines the type of Cyrus with that of Moses, Jehovah’s “shepherd,” who led Israel through “the deep”.
In the other, he combines the type of Cyrus with that of David, Jehovah’s “anointed”.
The second of these instances pertains to the type of Cyrus the Persian’s universal conquests.
His universal mission is for the sake of the twelve–tribed kingdom of Israel—not for the sake of the Jews Cyrus the Persian released from captivity in Babylon.

The Davidic Monarchy.desc: A Davidic king was prosecuted on account of his people’s disloyalties to God in the pattern of emperor–vassal covenants and of a sacrificial lamb that acts as “an offering for guilt” under the Law of Moses.

Isaiah doesn’t predict the earthly mission of a spiritual messiah as an end–time event, only as one that God’s arm—his servant—points to it when seeking to renew end–time Israel’s allegiance to its God.
Part III of Isaiah’s Seven–Part Structure depicts the servant undergoing a descent phase of trials and afflictions in the pattern of King David that is the prelude to his ascent phase.
Jehovah first anoints his servant, an aspect that Isaiah covers under the servant’s Cyrus persona.

An emperor’s grasping of a vassal by the right hand signifies his appointing the vassal to a particular task—in this instance, the overthrow of nations and peoples in order to release Israel’s captives.
Upon God’s anointing his servant, the Spirit of Jehovah comes upon him as it did upon David.
A person’s anointing, on the one hand, and his Spirit endowment, on the other, however, are two inseparable messianic traits, as was the case with King David.
As God’s “day of vengeance” is an end–time event, the fuller context of the passage depicts the messianic mission of God’s end–time servant, not that of Jehovah/Jesus.

This transition from servanthood to sonship, applies to all end–time servants of God who fulfill roles as proxy saviors to God’s people under the terms of the Davidic Covenant. Part III of Isaiah’s Seven–Part Structure’s conjoining of its two units of material into a single whole—one dealing with the servant’s “son” phase, the other with his “servant” phase.
Many other servants of God reign with him in that glorious age, all of whom follow the same pattern of serving God’s people as kings and priests under the terms of the Davidic Covenant
They are “anointed” and endowed with God’s “Spirit”

In the course of acting as a proxy savior to God’s people in order to obtain their divine protection when their lives are imperiled, God’s servant suffers at the hands of vindictive and accusatory enemies from among his own people.

Like King Hezekiah, God’s servant “pours out his soul unto death” when answering for the disloyalties of God’s people under the terms of the Davidic Covenant, but when God empowers him he “divides the spoil with the mighty” as did King David.
In each case, the proxy savior’s descent phase leads to his ascent phase.
After the servant is “despised as a person” and “abhorred by his people”—yet proves faithful to God under all conditions in ministering to God’s people—Jehovah exalts and empowers him.
He becomes a power of salvation to God’s exiled peoples.
Upon the servant’s vanquishing the enemies of God’s people and dividing their spoil as did King David, he is crowned king by Israel’s tribes as was David.
The reestablishment of the Davidic monarchy appears a second time as an event connected to the servant’s vanquishing his people’s enemies in the pattern of King David.
That judge—God’s servant—prepares end–time Israel to meet Jehovah/Jesus at his coming by clearing away his people’s stumbling blocks.

Linking ideas to other parts of Isaiah’s prophecy—such as an endowment of God’s Spirit, the attributes of counsel, valor, and righteousness, and key words that act as codenames such as righteousness, mouth, and lips—designate mostly God’s servant in an end–time context as the subject of the passage but in a generic sense may apply to Jehovah himself, whom his servant and fellowservants seek to emulate.
The Davidic Monarchy.oref: Isaiah 42:1; Isaiah 48:16; Isaiah 61:1; Isaiah 63:11; Isaiah 9:6-7; Isaiah 28:29; Isaiah 46:11-13; Isaiah 49:26; Isaiah 41:2; Isaiah 46:11-13; Isaiah 49:2; Isaiah 57:18-19; Isaiah 11:1-5

The Davidic Monarchy.desc: His descent below all during his earthly ministry—when paying the price of his people’s spiritual salvation—accords with his glorious ascent above all as King of Zion.

Based on the interplay between God’s justice and mercy—in which justice must be served before mercy can operate—Jehovah’s fulfilling his proxy role on behalf of his people establishes the theological premise that makes possible humanity’s long–awaited reversal of covenant curses, including death, and constitutes the singular event Jehovah alone can accomplish from which all salvation derives.
The Davidic Monarchy.oref: Isaiah 25:7-8; Isaiah 26:19; Isaiah 44:22; Isaiah 52:1-3; Isaiah 53:5; Isaiah 65:19-25

The Davidic Monarchy.desc: The divine modesty of Israel’s King, who, besides passing through a multitude of other deprecating ordeals, is willing to be “despised and disdained by men, a man of grief, accustomed to suffering”.

The paradox of God’s people’s interpersonal relationships: that those who are most “vigilant for his word”—as evidenced by their searching the scriptures to see “whether those things are so” ({Acts 17:11})—should suffer most at the hands of ecclesiastical brethren who, to their own condemnation, hold fast to popular but scripturally unsupported “precepts of men”.
The Davidic Monarchy.oref: Isaiah 66:5; Isaiah 29:13; Isaiah 51:7; Isaiah 61:7; Isaiah 65:13-15; Isaiah 66:5

Rebuilding of the Temple.desc: Under his Cyrus persona, God’s end–time servant likewise announces the rebuilding of the temple in Jerusalem.

Identifying the servant’s Cyrus persona as God’s “servant” and “shepherd” links the rebuilding of the temple to Israel’s exodus out of Egypt under Moses, Israel’s “shepherd,” who led Israel through “the deep”.
The God who created the heavens and the earth cannot be contained in an earthly tabernacle.
Israel’s God dwells with his humble, repentant people.

The Reign of the Judges.desc: In that day—Israel’s darkest hour—certain “servants” of Jehovah act as his people’s proxy saviors, Jehovah saving them from destruction “for the sake of his servants,” their deliverers.
Israel’s end–time judges assist in purifying and sanctifying the establishment of God’s people so that Jehovah may reconstitute all institutions that once existed.
In the millennial age that ensues, both king and judges govern God’s people in the pattern of Moses and Israel’s judges.

Jehovah\u2019s Covenant.desc: Under the metaphor of a wife whom he remarries, Jehovah establishes his covenant.

The unconditional covenant blessings—(1) of a land endowed with a paradisiacal glory; (2) of offspring divinely protected; and (3) made after a cataclysmic destruction as in the days of Noah—are further complemented by God’s commissioning his elect as his priests and ministers in the pattern of the Levitical Covenant.
As God endowed his priests and Levites anciently with his holy Spirit, so he does his end–time elect.
That “nation” of God’s elect consists of those who respond positively to his end–time servant, whom Jehovah appoints to minister to them.
God makes his unconditional covenant with his elect through the agency of his servant.
On the heels of God’s end–time servant’s being “born”—being empowered of God to minister to his people—so is “born” the nation of God’s elect.
The nation of God’s people born in a “day”—God’s Day of Judgment—thus consists of those whom his servant rallies to God’s highest covenantal standard at the time God cleanses the earth of the wicked.

Zion as Jehovah\u2019s Residence.desc: At the end of the world, when he comes to institute his millennial reign of peace, Jehovah again manifests his presence as he did to Solomon and Israel’s elders at the dedication of the temple in Jerusalem and as he did to Moses and Israel’s elders on Mount Sinai.
Following an end–time war to end all wars, Zion and Jerusalem gain prominence as the source of Jehovah’s law and word—the terms of his covenant—that go forth to all nations.
To the city of God come even former enemies of his people when Jehovah glorifies his dwelling place in the sight of all nations.

The Creation.desc: By depicting God’s entire creation as a sequential phenomenon—one that becomes progressively more refined—Isaiah reveals its ultimate intent. First, there occurs the creation of the heavens and the earth out of preexisting materials.
God’s creation has a divine purpose.
In accordance with his divine plan, God creates man.
There comes the creation of nations and isles or continents.
The creation of a people of God follows.
Although they are his people, those on the Jacob/Israel level tend to love idols and forget their God.
Jehovah’s redeeming his people involves his intervening on their behalf.
Jehovah re–creates them, as it were, “from the dust”—from a chaotic or cursed condition—and empowers them.
As they covenant with him and keep his law and word, Jehovah re–creates them on the son/servant level and brings them home from their places of exile to the Promised Land.
Accompanying his people’s re–creation is God’s re–creation of the cosmos.

These redemptive events occur at the time the Creator of heaven and earth reverses the adverse circumstances of his end–time servant by re–creating him on the seraph level and empowering him to restore his people.
Many others at that time also ascend to exalted spiritual levels, fulfilling the ultimate purpose of God’s creation.

Paradise.desc: At the inception of the millennial age that precedes Jehovah’s coming to reign on the earth, a regeneration of the earth’s natural environment occurs, commencing in Zion.
In parallel with a regenerating wilderness, the bodies of God’s elect also regenerate as Jehovah’s coming draws near.
At Jehovah’s coming in glory, Zion and its stakes become established as the joyful abode of God’s elect:
Wild animals become tame and all creatures on the earth live in peace.
Every vestige of disharmony and oppression disappears from the earth.
Zion’s beauty surpasses previous experience as the earth’s millennial inhabitants partake of the spiritual and temporal salvation God promises those who prove loyal to him through the evil time.

King as Exemplar.details: Hezekiah’s role as an exemplar of his people in the second unit appears in part even in the first, in the imagery of eating cream and honey: just as Immanuel (historically identified as Hezekiah) eats cream and honey when Assyria invades the land of Immanuel So those who survive with him in the wilderness in that day eat cream and honey. The king and people alike pass through a time of trouble. In periods of political upheaval, Israelites at times resorted to the nomadic lifestyle of the patriarchs (cf. {1 Samuel 4:10; 2 Kings 13:5}).

The prophesied time of trouble finds fulfillment in the second unit, where Hezekiah and his people survive a protracted period of national distress: for two years—at Assyria’s incursion into Judea—both king and people must “eat what grows wild and . . . what springs up of itself.” But in the third year they are to “sow and harvest, plant vineyards and eat their fruit: the remnant of the house of Judah that survives shall once more take root below and bear fruit above.” Isaiah identifies that “remnant” (se’erit/peleta) as Zion/Jerusalem, denoting a distinct category of Jehovah’s people.

On the same occasion, Hezekiah’s mortal illness—from which Jehovah miraculously heals him—additionally reflects Hezekiah’s function as an exemplar of his people. Just as he survives a personal threat of death, so his people survive a national threat of death when Jehovah miraculously delivers them from the Assyrians. Both king and people demonstrate covenantal compliance toward Jehovah in the midst of life–threatening circumstances sufficient to warrant Jehovah’s intervention on their behalf.
What typifies Ahaz and his people in the face of the Syro–Ephraimite threat is that “the king’s mind and the minds of his people were shaken, as trees in a forest are shaken by a gale”

An analogous idea to that of an exemplar—an individual who personifies Jehovah’s people allegorically—occurs with regard to the Woman figure. The “young woman with child” (‘alma hara) who gives birth to Immanuel refers to a real individual, as does Isaiah’s wife, who, in the same historical context, gives birth to another portending son—the Woman figure nonetheless appears throughout the Book of Isaiah as a representation of Jehovah’s people. The second unit depicts her as the “Virgin Daughter of Zion” (betulat bat siyyon) and the “Daughter of Jerusalem” (bat yerusalayim), who, in the presence of the loyal Davidic king now in power (Hezekiah), laughs the Assyrian king to scorn.

A movement from the first unit to the second thus actualizes the idea of Jehovah’s deliverance of his people that is implicit in the name “Immanuel.” In the first unit, the “young woman” or “damsel” (‘alma) names her son Immanuel (“God is with us”), voicing an assurance that Jehovah will deliver his people (cf. {Psalm 46:5–7}).

In the second unit, a “remnant” (se’erit/peleta) of Jehovah’s people—represented by the “Virgin Daughter of Zion” and the “Daughter of Jerusalem”—actually experiences that deliverance. Jehovah delivers Zion/Jerusalem’s children, who have “reached the point of birth,” together with their king, their intercessor and covenantal proxy. The birth or rebirth of Jehovah’s people to a higher spiritual plane nuances a theme developed in Part I. Being ransomed from destruction upon passing Jehovah’s tests of loyalty is one manifestation of such rebirth.

Prophetic Paradigm.desc: The prophet is among his people

Prophetic Paradigm.details: The symbolic act of cleansing the lips resembles the Egyptian rite of the Opening of the Mouth with an adze of meteoric iron, which, in the older Egyptian temple literature, represents an initiatory phase in the king’s ritual ascent to deification.

Isaiah’s being declared clean thus coincides with his being healed so that he can again speak and accept his prophetic call: “Then I heard the voice of my Lord say, ‘Whom shall I send? Who will go for us?’ And I replied, ‘Here am I; send me!’”

Instead of bringing healing to his people, he must “make the heart of these people grow fat, dull their ears and shut their eyes—lest they see [r’h] with their eyes and hear [sm‘] with their ears, understand [byn] in their heart, and repent [swb] and be healed [rp’]!”

Covenantal Naming.details: As a paradigm of spiritual ascent, Isaiah represents a superlative category of Jehovah’s salvation. His celestial accession, which models itself on the seraphs, reflects his attaining an increasingly sanctified state.
Such celestial accession is held out as a spiritual goal for all. Jehovah’s naming or renaming a person or people occurs whenever they assume, or are urged to assume, a higher spiritual calling.
Covenantal Naming.oref: Isaiah 43:1; Isaiah 45:3-4; Isaiah 49:1; Isaiah 56:5; Isaiah 62:2; Isaiah 65:15

Hezekiah\u2019s Ascent.desc: Jehovah’s deliverance of Zion/Jerusalem follows its passing his test of loyalty
Passing the test qualifies it for a ministering role to those of Jehovah’s people who have yet to pass such a test

The ministering role Zion/Jerusalem assumes, in effect, parallels Hezekiah’s initial role when the king ministered to those whose loyalties Jehovah was testing, to whom Hezekiah served as an exemplar.
Hezekiah’s test was more severe than that of his people, involving his suffering almost to death
The spiritual category to which Hezekiah ascends appears the same as was Isaiah’s at first
Hezekiah’s account of his illness, in which he believes he is dying, shows him bewailing the fact that he may not now “see Jehovah in the land of the living”.
Hezekiah\u2019s Ascent.details: Perhaps inspired by Isaiah—his prophet–mentor—Hezekiah’s spiritual goal was evidently to see Jehovah as Isaiah had seen him

Hezekiah\u2019s Ascent.desc: The idea of seeing and knowing Jehovah personally is a declared goal for his people in the Book of Isaiah
Isaiah informs Hezekiah that at some point Judah will go into exile in Babylon
Yet upon passing Jehovah’s severer test of his loyalty, Hezekiah evidently realizes his cherished goal. Hezekiah replies self–assuredly.
Finally, those who have yet to pass a test of their loyalty are identified as Jacob/Israel
Included in that category are the “cities of Judah,” to which Jehovah sends Zion/Jerusalem as a messenger of good tidings
Those good tidings, however, involve seeing Jehovah as an attainable goal: “Behold your God!”
