Allegiance.desc: The king of Assyria may conquer the whole world, but he and his ilk don’t prevail for long

Idolatry.details: Babylon’s Idols Seduce People away from God
Idolatry.oref: Isaiah 39:2; Isaiah 40:19; Isaiah 42:8; Isaiah 42:17; Isaiah 43:4; Isaiah 44:9-17; Isaiah 45:20; Isaiah 46:1-6; Isaiah 48:5-10

Idolatry.desc: Spiritual blindness—resulting from an entrenched culture of materialism—makes God’s people trust in “gods that cannot save” when trouble looms

1.desc: Certain “brethren” who exercise ecclesiastical authority “abhor” and “exclude” persons who are vigilant for God’s word

2.desc: In the end, however, God appoints as his priests and ministers those who suffer “shouted insults” and “twofold shame” for his sake

Old Jerusalem.desc: Isaiah accuses the city’s leaders of covenant rebellion, idolatry, and injustice, especially towards the poor.
God will judge the city by sending other nations to conquer Israel.
Isaiah says this will be like a purifying fire that burns away all that is worthless among his people.

New Jerusalem.desc: But this fire doesn’t only destroy, it will also create a new Jerusalem populated by a remnant of Israel that has repented and turned back to God. Through these events God’s kingdom will come and all nations will gather at the temple in Jerusalem to learn of God’s justice.
This will bring about an age of universal peace and harmony.

Isaiah\u2019s Vision.desc: Isaiah is surrounded by heavenly creatures, all shouting that God is “holy, holy, holy.”
Isaiah suddenly realizes just how corrupt he and his people are, and he’s certain that he’ll be destroyed by God’s holiness.
Instead, God’s holiness, in the form of a burning coal, comes and burns Isaiah, not to destroy him, but rather to purify him of his sin.
As Isaiah ponders this strange experience, God commissions him with a difficult task. Isaiah is to continue announcing the coming judgment...
...but since Israel has already reached a point of no return, his warnings will have the paradoxical effect of hardening their hearts.
However, Isaiah is to trust in God’s plan—Israel will undergo its own purification like Isaiah.
Isaiah\u2019s Vision.details: It will be chopped down like a tree, with its stump scorched and burned, but God says that this smoldering stump is a “holy seed” that will survive on into the future. It’s a small sign of hope. but who or what is the holy seed?

Ahaz and the Shoot.desc: Isaiah confronts Ahaz, a descendant of David and king of Jerusalem, and announces his downfall.
God says that the great empire of Assyria will chop Israel down and devastate the land...
...but there’s hope! Because of God’s promise to David, he will send a new king named “Immanuel,” or “God with us.”
Immanuel’s kingdom will free God’s people from violent, oppressive empires.
This coming king is like a small shoot of new growth emerging from the old stump of David’s family, the holy seed.
This king will be empowered by God's Spirit to rule over a new Jerusalem and bring forth justice for the poor.
All nations will look to this messianic king for guidance, and his kingdom will transform all creation, bringing peace.

0.desc: Assyria’s world power would one day be replaced by the empire of Babylon, a nation that was even more destructive and arrogant.

1.desc: Babylon’s kings would claim that they were higher than all other gods…

2.desc: ...and so God vows to bring Babylon down.

Two Cities.details: The “lofty city” that’s exalted itself over God and has become corrupt and unjust. It’s a poetic archetype of rebellious humanity and is described with language borrowed from Isaiah’s earlier depictions of Jerusalem, Assyria, and Babylon, all blended together. This city is destined for ruin,
The “lofty city” will one day be replaced by the New Jerusalem where God’s kingdom reigns over a redeemed humanity from among all nations and where there’s no more death or suffering.

Leaders Condemned.desc: ...for turning to Egypt for military protection against Assyria.
Isaiah knows that their plan will backfire, and tells the leaders that only trust in their God and repentance can save Israel now.

Hezekiah\u2019s Rise.desc: Just as Isaiah had predicted, the Assyrian armies attack the city.
Hezekiah humbles himself before God and prays for divine deliverance.
The city is miraculously saved overnight.

0.desc: Hezekiah tries to impress the Babylonians by showing off everything in Jerusalem’s treasury and palaces.

2.desc: Isaiah predicts that this “ally” will one day betray him and return as an enemy to conquer Jerusalem.
2.details: Based on {2 Kings 24–25}, Isaiah was right. Over one hundred years later. Babylon turned on Jerusalem, destroyed the city and its temple, and carried away Israelites into exile in Babylon.

Comfort, Comfort My People.desc: The people are told that the Babylonian exile is over. Israel’s sin has been dealt with, and a new era is beginning.

Israel should return home, where God himself will bring his kingdom to Jerusalem and allow all nations to see his glory. The day of future hope has come and that God is fulfilling his prophetic promises.
The prophet expresses his hopes that Israel will respond by becoming God’s “servant” after experiencing his justice and mercy, going on to share with the other nations what God is truly like.

The Trial.desc: Unfortunately, that’s not what happens. Israel, instead of bearing witness to all nations, starts complaining and accusing God: “The Lord doesn’t pay attention to our trouble, he ignores our cause.”
The Babylonian exile has caused Israel to lose faith in their God; they start to think that maybe he’s not all that powerful. Maybe the gods of Babylon are greater.
Exile into Babylon was not divine neglect, but a divinely orchestrated judgment for Israel’s sin.
It was for the sake of Israel’s return home that God raised up Persia to conquer Babylon and to fulfill Isaiah’s prophetic word ({Isaiah 13:17}).

The right conclusion that Israel should draw is that their God is the king of history, not their idols. In the fall of Babylon and the rise of the Persian king Cyrus, Israel should see God’s hand at work…
...and become his servant who will bear witness to the other nations.

A \u201cNew Thing\u201d.desc: However, at the end of the trial in chapter 48, we find that Israel is still just as rebellious and hardhearted as their ancestors. disqualifying themselves from being God’s servant to the nations.
God still has a mission to bless all the nations. however, so the prophet says that God will do a “new thing” to solve this problem.

Servant's Mission.desc: God gives this servant the title “Israel”
The Servant's Mission is (1) to Restore Israel
The Servant's Mission is (2) to be A Light to the Nations

1A.desc: Ensign to the Nations

1B.desc: Ensign to the Nations

2B.desc: Roads and Highways

3B.desc: Kingdoms

Servant is Rejected and Killed.desc: This servant will bring about God’s kingdom by being rejected, beaten, and ultimately killed by his own people, accused and sentenced to death on behalf of the sins of his people.
His death will be a sacrifice of atonement for the people’s evil and rebellion

Servant Lives Again.desc: The servant does die, but then suddenly comes back to life.

Two Ways to Respond.desc: Some will respond with humility, turn from their sins, and accept what the servant did on their behalf. These people are also called “servants” or “the seed” calling back to the “holy seed” from chapter 6.
These people are the ones who will experience the blessing of the messianic kingdom (ch. 55).
Others, however, will reject both the servant and his servants and are simply called “the wicked.”

A1.desc: All Nations Invited to Join God’s Covenant Family

A2.desc: All Nations Invited to Join God’s Covenant Family

B1.desc: Contrast Between the Wicked and the Servants

B2.desc: Contrast Between the Wicked and the Servants

C1.desc: Prayer of Repentance

C2.desc: Prayer of Repentance

Nations Invited.desc: In the renewed world of God’s kingdom. people from all nations are invited to join the servant s in God’s covenant family, so that they, too, can know their Creator and Redeemer.

Wicked vs. Servants.desc: The contrast the destiny of the servants with that of the wicked who persecute them.

Wicked vs. Servants.details: God will bring his justice down upon those who pollute his good world with evil through selfishness and idolatry, removing them from his city forever.
The servants who are humble and repent will instead inherit the new Jerusalem –an image of the renewed creation, where death and suffering are gone forever.

Prayers of Repentance.desc: The servant confesses Israel’s sin and grieve over all the evil that they see in the world around them,
...asking for God’s kingdom to come here on earth as it is in heaven.

Poems Announcing God\u2019s Kingdom.desc: The Spirit–empowered servant announces the good news of God’s kingdom to the poor...
...by reaffirming all the promises of hope from earlier in the book.
The new Jerusalem, inhabited by God’s servants will be the place from which God’s justice and mercy now out Into the world.

4 Agents.details: A Davidic figure who embodies the righteous functions and attributes of past Davidic kings such as David, Solomon, and Hezekiah as well as of Israelite heroes such as Abraham, Moses, and Joshua.
The Righteous Warrior figure serves both as a paradigm of Jehovah’s people and as Jehovah’s agent for delivering them.
The Cyrus figure sets a precedent for restoring Jerusalem.

3 Linked Events.desc: The metaphor of Jehovah’s “hand” (yad) links three events:
3 Linked Events.details: In each instance, the intervention of Jehovah’s hand occasions the deliverance of a “remnant” (se’ar) of Jehovah’s people from their dispersed condition among the nations.

3 Linked Events.desc: [Event 2] A new conquest of the Promised Land
[Event 3] A new exodus out of exile

1B.desc: Ensign

2A.desc: "Sprig of Jesse", Ensign

2B.desc: Hand

Cumulative Themes I \u2013 III.desc: [Part I] A reversal of circumstances between Zion and non-Zion
[Part II] The coexistence of two contrasting peoples and their kings
Cumulative Themes I \u2013 III.details: Babylon and its King; Israel and a Davidic King (King of Zion)

Cumulative Themes I \u2013 III.desc: [Part III] The idea of a single, composite entity made up of a number of historical types.
Cumulative Themes I \u2013 III.details: By universalizing the idea of a composite entity, and by juxtaposing that entity with Zion, Part IV redefines the idea of a reversal of circumstances between Zion and non-Zion.
Cumulative Themes I \u2013 III.oref: Isaiah 13:1; Isaiah 21:9; Isaiah 47:1; Isaiah 13:17; Isaiah 14:25; Isaiah 14:29; Isaiah 15:1; Isaiah 17:1; Isaiah 18:1; Isaiah 19:1; Isaiah 20:3; Isaiah 21:11; Isaiah 21:13; Isaiah 23:1

Cumulative Themes I \u2013 III.desc: [Parts I↔III] persons who are redeemed in the place Zion comprise those of Jacob/Israel who repent/return
[Parts II↔III] To qualify for Jehovah’s redemption, the latter are required to pass an important test of their loyalty in a time of trouble
[Parts II↔III] after which Jehovah “comforts” or “consoles” them (nhm)

While Zion’s birth or rebirth occurs when Jehovah delivers his people from the Assyrian power on account of a righteous Davidic king, Jehovah’s vassal (see Part II), it here receives the added dimension of Jacob/Israel’s repentance and return to the place Zion in an exodus out of Assyria and out of all the places where Jehovah had scattered them
Alternatively, those of Jacob/Israel who do not repent/return are subject to the king of Assyria, Jehovah’s agent of punishment

The type of Hezekiah as a righteous descendant of David, heir to David’s throne, thus appears cumulatively in Isaiah 9 . This chapter, which opens the first unit, portends Israel’s return from exile by depicting Jehovah’s making glorious, at the last, the Sea Route to the territory of the “nations” or “Gentiles” (gôyîm) through “the lands of Zebulun and Naphtali”

1A.desc: the motif of dividing “spoil” (salal) + the idea of “harvest time” (qasir)

1B.desc: corresponds to the dividing of “spoil” (salal) following Assyria’s overthrow +  matches Judah’s renewed “harvest” (qsr) after the Assyrian threat has passed

2A.desc: the smashing of the “yoke” (‘ol), “staff” (matteh), and “rod” (sebet), “as in the Day of Midian”

2B.desc: parallels the removal of Assyria’s “yoke” (‘ol), “staff” (matteh), and “rod” (sebet) “as when he [Jehovah] smote the Midianites at the Rock of Oreb”

3A.desc: ; a ruler on David’s “throne” (kise’) who upholds “justice” (mispat) and “righteousness” (sedaqa) + the “son” or vassal (ben) whom Jehovah appoints to David’s throne

3B.desc: resembles a judge on David’s “throne” (kisse’) who upholds “justice” (mispat) and “righteousness” (sedeq) after tyrants and oppressors are destroyed from the earth + compares with the “son” (ben) Immanuel who, with his people, survives Assyria’s invasion of the land of Immanuel

Davidic Ascention\u2194Return from Exhil.desc: conquest of the forces of chaos in a great victory as of light over darkness
Davidic Ascention\u2194Return from Exhil.details: The psalm depicts the conquest of the forces of chaos as the smashing of the enemy’s “yoke” (‘ô/), “staff” (matteh), and “rod” (sebet) in a great victory as of light over darkness
The terms “burdened,” “submission,” and “subjected” (v 4) all reflect bondage—a covenant curse—from which the king now releases his people.
The reestablishment of “justice” (mispat) and “righteousness” (sedeq) (v 7) signifies a new creation of cosmic order.94

New Creation.desc: universal harmony ensues among men and beasts

2.desc: he smites the earth, slaying the wicked

3.desc: the knowledge of Jehovah fills the earth

Cyrus\u2019s Name.desc: not only does Jehovah call the Cyrus figure by name
Jacob/Israel’s endowment of a name, as with the naming of the Cyrus figure
provides immunity when passing through restraining elements at their exodus to the Promised Land:
Such immunity is essential at the time Jacob/Israel returns from exile from the four directions of the earth

3 Redemptive Roles.desc: Bringing about their return from throughout the earth

3 Redemptive Roles.details: A new exodus, new wandering in the wilderness, a new conquest

Babylon\u2019s Demise.desc: [Unit 1] Babylon will be thrown down “as God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah”.
[Unit 1] Babylon will not be reinhabited through all generations.
[Unit 1] wild animals will infest Babylon and jackals will cry out from its palaces.
[Unit 1] Babylon’s king will be hewn down and cast away unburied.
[Unit 1] Jehovah will sweep Babylon with the broom of destruction, cutting off its name and remnant.
[Unit 1] Babylon will fall and its idols will be razed to the ground.
[Unit 1] Jehovah will lay waste and destroy Tyre, which the Babylonians founded for shipping.
[Unit 2] Babylon will descend into the dust when catastrophe overtakes it suddenly.
[Unit 2] fire will consume Babylon’s prognosticators, burning them up like stubble.

A2.desc: election, royal accession, and mission to the nations of Jehovah’s servant

B1.desc: attributes of the Servant figure

B2.desc: attributes of Jehovah  who commissions him

C1.desc: motifs of a “bruised reed” and “dim wick”

C2.desc: establishment of universal justice

Glory\u2194Ignominy.desc: Jehovah establishes Zion as a place of refuge for his long–suffering people when their enemies fall victim to Assyria’s tyranny.
Israel rules over its captors at the time Babylon’s king figure meets his end.
A nation dreaded far and wide, which annexes others’ lands, is made to bring tribute to Zion.
Babylon’s “glory” (tip’eret) is thrown down as was Sodom and Gomorrah.
Its king’s “glory” (ge’on) is cast into Sheol, the realm of the dead.
The “glory” (ge’on/kabod) of the nations and of Jehovah’s alienated people turns into ignominy.

Components of Babylon.oref: Isaiah 13:14; Isaiah 14:2, 12, 26, 32; Isaiah 15:1-9; Isaiah 16:2-4, 6-14; Isaiah 17:1-3, 12-14; Isaiah 19:1-16; Isaiah 20:3-6; Isaiah 21:16-17; Isaiah 23:1-14; Isaiah 47:5

Components of Babylon.desc: the tyrants and oppressors of the earth

Components of Babylon.oref: Isaiah 15:6, 9; Isaiah 16:8; Isaiah 17:12-13; Isaiah 18:2, 7; Isaiah 19:5-6; Isaiah 23:2-4, 11

Babylon \u21cc Universal.desc: The setting is the “Day of Jehovah” (yom yhwh)
A day that sees “destruction throughout the earth”
The earth jolting out of place
The hearts of all men melting
Everyone fleeing to his own land
Babylon is the subject of worldwide catastrophe
Dead kings of the nations—vassals of the king of Babylon—receiving him with wonder in Sheol, the world of departed spirits
He who “subdued the nations,” who “made the earth shake and kingdoms quake”
whose vassals “filled the face of the earth with cities”
is himself brought low when he perishes
The “whole earth” rejoices at his departure and rests from his tyranny
A conclusing verse mentions “the whole earth” and “all nations”
A passage that anticipates the reign of an ideal Davidic “judge” (sopet)
interjects an oracle that depicts the ruin of Moab
the Davidic king will accede to the throne “when oppressors are no more and violence has ceased and tyrants are destroyed from the earth”
A passage describing the overnight annihilation of “many peoples in an uproar, who rage like the raging of the seas, tumultuous nations, in commotion like the turbulence of mighty waters”
concludes an oracle that addresses Aram and Jehovah’s idolatrous people
“All you who live in the world, you inhabitants of the earth, look to the ensign when it is lifted up in the mountains; heed the trumpet when it is sounded!”
A verse that allegorically depicts the mission of Jehovah’s ideal vassal appears in an oracle concerning the dreaded nation (Assyria) that encroaches upon others
A universal perspective further appears in the motif of a highway that reaches from Assyria to Egypt
and in the blessed state of the world that ensues after the catastrophe. In that blessedness a transformed Assyria, Egypt, and Israel share alike
Meanwhile, Babylon’s fall
affects the uttermost reaches of civilization
calamity overtaking even wandering nomads
The revelers among Jehovah’s people perish at the hands of the same army that destroys Babylon
“An oracle concerning Tyre” depicts Jehovah’s stretching out his hand (yad) over the Sea (yam) and distressing kingdoms
Tyre is depicted as the “merchant of nations”
an imperial city whose “traders” (sohareha) were princes, whose merchants were the world’s celebrities
As the mercantile arm of Babylon, Tyre concludes the first unit.
Babylon’s demise, moreover, resembles Edom’s in Part I: just as Edom’s Sodom–and Gomorrah type of destruction
in the “Day of Jehovah”
typifies the desolation of the earth and the world and of all nations and peoples
so Babylon’s destruction “as Sodom and Gomorrah”
in the “Day of Jehovah”
is synonymous with the desolation of the earth and the world
and of all nations who comprise Greater Babylon
The common evils that befall Babylon and Edom—cosmic cataclysm
lands infested by wild beasts and birds of prey
never to be resettled
the cutting off of both name and remnant and so forth—represent covenantal malediction.

1A.desc: [Tyre] A common harlot imagery identifies Tyre in the first unit with Babylon in the second: Tyre hires herself out “to all kingdoms of the world on the face of the earth”

1B.desc: [Babylon] Babylon, “Mistress of Kingdoms,” has exerted herself from her youth for her “procurers” (soharayik)

2A.desc: [Tyre] Tyre, a “ravished virgin,” will “frolic no more” and “find no rest”

2B.desc: [Babylon] Babylon, whose “nakedness is exposed” and whose “shame is uncovered,” is reduced to a slave girl

3A.desc: [Tyre] Tyre, who reared young men and raised virgins, is rendered barren, bereft of children

3B.desc: [Babylon] bereavement of children and widowhood overtake Babylon, both in one “day”

Self\u2013Exalation.desc: Babylon’s self–exaltation, precedes its fall: “Catastrophe shall overtake you, which you shall not know how to avert by bribes; disaster shall befall you from which you cannot ransom yourself: there shall come upon you sudden ruin such as you have not imagined”

The nations who comprise Greater Babylon follow the same pattern of selfexaltation leading to their fall: “We have heard of the glories of Moab, of its excessive pride and boasting and of its outbursts of false propaganda”
but “Moab’s glory shall become ignominy” and those left of its multitude shall be “of no account”
“The wisest of Pharaoh’s advisers give absurd counsel. How can you say to Pharaoh, ‘We ourselves are as wise as the first rulers’?”
“They have misled Egypt in all that it does, causing it to stagger like a drunkard into his vomit”
“Who devised this stratagem against Tyre, the imperial [city] . . . ? Jehovah of Hosts devised it, to make all glorying in excellence a profanity, and the world’s celebrities an utter execration”
Self–exaltation—an ultimate type of wickedness—is the basis upon which Jehovah humiliates Babylon and all who exalt themselves with her.
Self\u2013Exalation.details: Babylon’s humiliation in Part IV subsumes the idea of the nations who suffer ruin in Part I. Zion’s exaltation, on the other hand, subsumes the idea of Zion’s rebirth. While the themes of ruin and rebirth and of punishment and deliverance here occur cumulatively, Part IV redefines these concepts to show that ruin and punishment ultimately involve humiliation, and that rebirth and deliverance involve exaltation. It also identifies non–Zion, which is ruined, punished, and humiliated as Babylon, comprising all who stand in defiance of Jehovah. In the anti–Jehovah climate Babylon exemplifies, Jehovah’s people suffer ignominy in the interim before Jehovah redeems them.

Self\u2013Exalation.desc: As the motif of “glory” implies the humiliation of Babylon heralds the exaltation of Zion, and vice versa

1A.desc: Jehovah forgives Zion’s inhabitants their iniquity

1B.desc: he doesn’t forgive arch  Babylon’s inhabitants until they die

2A.desc: Jehovah lays a sure foundation in Zion

2B.desc: he removes arch Babylon’s foundation

3A.desc: Jehovah protects Zion in his Day of Judgment

3B.desc: he doesn’t protect arch Babylon in that day

4A.desc: Zion enjoys peace and an absence of fear

4B.desc: fear and terror overtake arch Babylon

8B.desc: arch Babylon’s children scatter and die

9B.desc: arch Babylon’s land decays and dries up

11B.desc: arch Babylon’s rule in the earth ends

13A.desc: Jehovah clothes Zion in robes of glory

14A.desc: Zion, jubilant, spreads abroad and inherits nations

14B.desc: Babylon, speechless, ceases to rule kingdoms

15A.desc: Zion gathers up Jehovah’s people who were outcasts

15B.desc: Babylon shows them no mercy, yoking down young and old

16A.desc: Zion, forsaken and cast off, Jehovah espouses anew

16B.desc: Babylon, espoused and secure, he widows and bereaves

18B.desc: Babylon, unable to ransom herself, he visits with disaster

19A.desc: Zion lives through the devouring fire

20A.desc: Babylon, which exalts itself, falls into the dust

20B.desc: Zion, humiliated and oppressed under Babylon’s domination, rises, exalted, from the dust

Babylon\u2019s Humiliation.desc: Jehovah puts an end to the arrogance of insolent men and humbles the pride of tyrants
Babylon, the most exalted of kingdoms, the glory and pride of Chaldeans, is thrown down as Sodom and Gomorrah
Moab’s pride and boasting
turns to ignominy and dejection
Aram’s and Jacob’s glory wanes as their fatness of body wastes away
an aggressive nation, dreaded far and wide, is made to bring tribute to Mount Zion
Pharaoh’s counselors, who regard themselves the equals of Egypt’s founding fathers
cause Egypt to stagger like a drunkard into his vomit
Egypt, looked up to for help against Assyria
is exiled naked and barefoot with buttocks uncovered
Babylon, indulging  itself in feasting and drinking
is razed to the ground
the city of revelry, resounding with loud cheers
shamefully flees in disarray
Shebna the steward, who vaingloriously exalts himself
is thrust out of office, a disgrace to his master’s house
Tyre, the festive city, whose merchants were the world’s celebrities
is forgotten, its celebrities made an execration
Babylon, securely enthroned as Mistress of Kingdoms, is banished into obscurity
Babylon, a pampered lady, delicate and refined
is reduced to servitude
Babylon, exalting herself as the Eternal Mistress
turns into stubble
[King of Babylon] When the king of Babylon ascends, godlike, in the heavens—to the “utmost heights of Zaphon”
[King of Babylon] Jehovah thrusts him down to Sheol, to the “uttermost depths of the Pit”
[King of Babylon] After he rises gloriously as the morning star, he falls, ingloriously, from the heavens
[King of Babylon] After he commands the nations, Jehovah hews him down to earth
[King of Babylon] his corpse moldering, unburied, in a bed of maggots
[King of Babylon] After he makes the earth shake and kingdoms quake, dead men mock and revile him
[King of Babylon] The king of Babylon, hewer of the cedars of Lebanon, Jehovah lays low

1A.desc: [Babylon] Comes from the north

1B.desc: [Assyria] Comes from the north

2B.desc: [Assyria] Hews down the cedars of Lebanon

3B.desc: [Assyria] Conquers the world

5B.desc: [Assyria] Imposes his yoke of servitude on his people

Chaos & Creation.desc: Within the structured context of Isaiah 41, the wilderness regenerates
...immediately following Jacob/Israel’s threshing of mountains and hills into dust and chaff

The concluding verse of the passage confirms their interrelatedness: Jehovah’s hand and the Holy One of Israel, respectively, are acknowledged as “doing” (‘sh) and “creating” (br’) what has been described
In other words, the rendering of hostile elements into chaos
...form a concerted division of labors between "hand" and Holy One.
Within the broader context of this chapter, moreover, such structuring ties together the redemptive events of Jacob/Israel’s return from exile,
...and, in this instance, a new wandering in the wilderness.
In summary, the passages cited speak, with varying emphases, of the same end-time sequence that links them: a prophetic figure righteousness,
...serves as a paradigm and helper of Jehovah’s collective servant Jacob/Israel
For Jacob/Israel, the return march leads through a regenerating wilderness,

Cumulative Themes I \u2013 IV.desc: [Part I] Reversal of circumstances between Zion and non-Zion
[Part II] Coexistence of two antithetical peoples and their kings
[Part III] Composite of types to depict an ideal agent of Jehovah’s redemption, an exemplar and paradigm of Jehovah’s people
[Part IV] Composite of types to depict a pluralistic arch entity (Babylon) that is the oppressor and opponent of Zion

1A.desc: [Earth] The grape vines of the earth languish

1B.desc: [Righteous] While Jehovah’s fruitful vineyard, hitherto a fruitless national locale, Now extends to the world

2A.desc: [Nations] Jehovah’s punitive vintage and threshing of the nations

2B.desc: [Righteous] Is survived by a people whom Jehovah gleans from the torrent of the River (Assyria) to the streams of Egypt

3A.desc: [Enemies] The enemies of his people, Jehovah utterly banishes

3B.desc: [Righteous] But his lost and outcast people Jehovah restores from exile

4A.desc: [Earth] The elite and proud peoples of the earth, Jehovah lays low in the dust

4B.desc: [Righteous] But his lowly ones he revives from the dust

5B.desc: [Righteous] Who “hope” in or “wait” for him amid troubled times

6B.desc: [Righteous] But he delivers his poor and needy

7B.desc: [Righteous] While to his people Jehovah is a refuge in the day of calamity

8A.desc: [Nations] The dead lords of the nations don’t resurrect and live again

8B.desc: [Righteous] But Jehovah’s dead resurrect and live again on the earth when the earth casts up its dead

9B.desc: [Righteous] Whereas he exalts his righteous ones in the earth

10B.desc: [Righteous] With a sumptuous feast of cakes and wine for the righteous of all peoples

11A.desc: [Earth] The cessation of joy for the earth’s cursed inhabitants

11B.desc: [Righteous] Contrasts renewed joy and singing for Jehovah’s blessed people throughout the earth

12B.desc: [Righteous] But he saves the righteous one

City \u21cc Moab \u2461.desc: Moab’s pride and aggression manifest enmity toward Jacob/Israel by a kindred people.
The parallel fates suffered by Moab and the city—the overthrow of habitations

City \u21cc Earth.desc: a curse overtakes the earth and its inhabitants
in the form of silencing of joy and lack of wine
which curse repeats itself upon the city and its silence of joy and lack of wine
City \u21cc Earth.details: The passage’s two “city” references (qirya/‘ir) are further interjected by a reference to the “earth” (’ares)

City \u21cc Earth.desc: The maledictory passage itself commences with curses upon the earth and its inhabitants
City \u21cc Earth.details: This takes the form of decimation of population and withering vegetation (Isaiah 24:6–7) continues with the above-named curses in common, and concludes with curses upon the city in the form of destruction of gates and dwelling places

City \u21cc Heathen.desc: The “city” is as “heathen mansions” or “a citadel of aliens” (armon zarim)
and as a “city [or community] of tyrannous nations” (qiryat goyim ‘arisim)

City \u21cc Jacob\/Israel.desc: Jacob’s idolatry is a cause of covenant curses upon the city
These curses include the habitation of the city’s ruins by beasts of the field

Cumulative Themes I \u2013 V.desc: [Ruin] Destruction and desolation awaits the earth

\ud83c\udd85 Ruin.desc: The heavens clothed with the blackness of mourning
And vanishing from view through smoke
The earth wearing away like a garment, its inhabitants perishing like vermin
Mountains and hills collapsing and moving out of place
The sea and rivers drying up

\ud83c\udd85 Rebellion.desc: Oppressors eating and drinking their own flesh and blood
The sinners of Jehovah’s people selling themselves
The reprobate of Israel being cut off
Desolation, ruin, famine, the sword, and captivity coming as a curse upon Jehovah’s alienated people
And the pseudo–righteous of Jehovah’s people agonizing at Jehovah’s judgments

Zion, experiencing Jehovah’s displeasure

Before Jehovah blesses her with an endowed posterity
A bejeweled place of abode
And his divine protection

Zion/Jerusalem drinks from Jehovah’s left hand the cup of his wrath
Before Jehovah gives it back into the hand of his people’s tormentors
Zion, wretched, without consolation
Lies prostrate on the ground, its oppressors riding roughshod over it
Before these same chastisements turn on its oppressors
Righteousness, in whose heart abides Jehovah’s law, who endure reproach and ridicule, before Jehovah destroys their revilers
Zion, afflicted, thinking herself forsaken and forgotten
And Zion bereaved, barren, exiled, and banished
Before her children return to her from among the nations
Before kings adore her
And Jehovah comforts her
The followers of righteousness, who seek Jehovah, living solitary like Abraham, suffering barrenness like Sarah
Before Jehovah multiplies their posterity and regenerates their wilderness
Zion, fearful, reproached, and ashamed
Forsaken, rejected, and forlorn
Before Jehovah receives her back and espouses her anew
Zion, experiencing Jehovah’s displeasure
Before she enjoys his loving compassion by an immutable covenant
Zion, living as a wretch, tempest–tossed and disconsolate
Before Jehovah blesses her with an endowed posterity
A bejeweled place of abode
And his divine protection

\ud83c\udd85 Salvation.desc: Jehovah sends forth his law and word to the nations
Refines the house of Jacob for his name’s sake
Calls his people from afar, like Abraham
Releases his people from captivity and from bands
Restores his exiles to Zion
Sustains the exiles on their return home
Rebuilds and resettles Zion’s ruins
Causes Zion’s ravagers and devourers to depart
Ends fear for his righteous people
Restores peace to Zion
Restores compassion and comforts to his people
Renews joy and rejoicing among his people
Expands Zion’s dwelling places
Regenerates Zion’s land
Protects Zion
Delivers Zion’s children
Heralds his return to Zion
Chooses Zion as his bride
Causes all flesh to behold Zion’s deliverance
Empowers, enthrones, and exalts Zion
Causes Zion’s offspring to dispossess the nations
And beautifies Zion’s land with precious stones

Fleeing Babylon.desc: Those who comply with Jehovah’s admonition to flee Babylon
For example, participate in a new exodus
It involves Jehovah’s people exiting Babylon when the announcement goes forth to the end of the earth that Jehovah has redeemed his servant Jacob
The expression “end of the earth” qeseh ha’ares
Denotes the universal nature of this call257 and thus the universality of both Babylon and the exodus
Jehovah’s salvation, in other words, extends to the “end of the earth” and no one is excluded who responds to his call.

The Composite City.desc: Chapter 1 introduces the reprobate city in a lament
Jehovah deals with the city, first, by avenging his “enemies”
The text depicts that act allegorically as Jehovah’s smelting away of “dross” and “alloy”
Second, Jehovah restores a righteous political government
in place of the current corrupt one
Jehovah initiates this cleansing of his people by restoring his hand over them
[Deliverance] Jehovah’s people who repent/return are ransomed
[Assention] by righteousness
[Punishment] while murderers, enemies, criminals, and sinners are destroyed.
The “city” of Zion in Isaiah 1:8 experiences a similar deliverance.
The Composite City.details: When Zion comes “under siege” (nesura), Jehovah “preserves” it, its survivors become as those who had escaped the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. Jehovah’s twofold response in dealing with the city—destroying its wicked elements and passing through the fire and ransoming those who repent/return—eventually gives way to two cities, one righteous, the other wicked.

The Composite City.desc: A passage in Isaiah 22 makes the transition toward this division. It depicts a “city of revelry” (qirya ‘aliza), a “tumultuous city” (‘ir homiya)
which forms a part of Greater Babylon developed in Part IV. Although contextually the city is the “city of David”
the city appears anonymously as if to denote an alien entity
Enemies batter down the city’s walls and its inhabitants are trodden underfoot—a covenant curse.
The Davidic connection, on the other hand, underscores the idea of an inviolable city of David. While Jehovah’s reprobate people and their leader are “cut off” (krt) and “fall” (npl)
others find surety in a Davidic “servant” (‘ebed)—Eliakim
Next, appears the anonymous “city of chaos” (qiryat tohu) in the first unit of Part V.
That expression, and the city’s description as “exalted” (nisgaba)
“entrenched” or “fortified” (besura)
“a citadel of aliens” (armon zarim)
and so forth, portrays an entity that can no longer be reclaimed by an appeal to repentance. We observe this foreboding element also in the way the text juxtaposes the doomed exalted city
with “our city”
the habitation of the righteous whom Jehovah “preserves” (tissor)
Those who keep faith with Jehovah experience salvation in the city and enjoy “perfect peace” (salom salom)
They live to tread the dust of the chaotic city underfoot
when Jehovah makes it a desolation
a forsaken habitation
a ruin, a heap, and no city
Isaiah 29, in a play on words, depicts Ariel—“the city where David lodged”—as an “altar hearth” (’ariel) during a siege
The Composite City.details: A dichotomy of thought surrounding the city prevails through the remainder of the passage.

The Composite City.desc: On the one hand, Jehovah lays the city low in the dust
its “crowds of evildoers” (hamon zedayik) and “violent mobs” (hamon ‘arisim) becoming but dust and flying chaff in a fiery conflagration
On the other hand, Zion remains inviolable against all the nations who amass against her. These nations vanish overnight as if they were a dream
The chapter then restates the above dichotomy.
A final reference to the wicked city in Isaiah 32 links together the motifs of a “city of revelry” (qirya ‘alliza)
a “citadel” (’armon), and a “tumultuous city” (hamon ‘ir)
That imagery denotes, contextually, a habitation of the godless, rogues, and carefree ones among Jehovah’s people
Jehovah levels the city by “flattening” or “abasement” (bassipla tispal ha‘ir)
and it becomes a place forsaken, a habitation of wild animals

The same passage, however, juxtaposes the wicked city with Jehovah’s righteous people. It depicts the latter as dwelling in an “abode of peace” (neweh salom) or “peaceable habitation” (menuhot sa’anannot)
Using this same imagery, the following chapter identifies the righteous city rhetorically as Zion/Jerusalem—a “city of solemn assemblies” (qiryat mo‘adenu), an “abode of peace” (naweh sa’anan)
The Composite City.details: This juxtaposition of two cities, both of which originate with Jehovah’s people, thus appears cumulatively, though briefly, beyond Isaiah 24–27.That the motif of a wicked city now ends, however, signifies that ultimately the righteous city prevails over its chaotic counterpart.

The Composite City.desc: The motif of a threatened “city” reappears
although the city— Zion/Jerusalem—proves inviolable “for the sake of my servant David”
Next, Jehovah personalizes the city the Cyrus figure builds as “my city” (‘iri)
while the “holy city” (‘ir haqqodes)  continues a series of narrowing definitions of the term.
The city—Zion/Jerusalem—puts on garments of glory and rises from the dust and from captivity
Zion further appears as the “city of Jehovah” (‘ir yhwh), the site of his sanctuary and place of his feet
Finally, Zion represents the “holy people” (‘am haqodes), those whom Jehovah redeems, a “city” (‘ir) sought for and not forsaken
The Composite City.details: The city of Isaiah 24–27 thus forms an integral part of a motif whose development commences prior to this material but culminates beyond it. The wicked city, moreover, which goes into the dust, is the antithesis of a righteous city that rises from the dust and prevails— Zion/Jerusalem. These identities suggest that the city metaphor subsumes the archetypes of Zion and Babylon. That idea finds support even where the city represents Jehovah’s reprobate people alone and in that the city becomes two cities—one righteous, the other wicked—from Isaiah 24–27 onward.

Universal Suffering.desc: [Suffering] The earth pines away and the world miserably perishes, the elite of the earth become wretched
the inhabitants of the earth who flee at the sound of terror, fall into a pit, and those who get up out of the pit are caught in a trap
Jehovah’s people remember Jehovah in their distress, pouring out silent prayers when his chastisements are upon them
like a woman about to give birth, who cries out from her pangs, so do his people as Jehovah’s coming draws near

[Wickedness] The “curse” (’ala) devours the earth because its inhabitants transgress Jehovah’s “law” (torot), alter his “ordinances” (hoq), and set at nought Jehovah’s “ancient covenant” (berit ‘olam, or “eternal covenant”)
Although Jehovah shows favor to the wicked, “they don’t learn righteousness” (bal lamad sedeq). Rather, in a “land of uprightness” or “proving-ground” (’eres nekohot) they remain “perverse” (‘awel)
Jehovah raises his (left) hand (yad), but people don’t perceive it. Too late, they perceive Jehovah’s zeal for his people when the “fire” (’es) prepared for his enemies devours them
[Remnant] Those “whose minds are steadfast” through trials, Jehovah “preserves in perfect peace”
But the oppressors of his people Jehovah “appoints to destruction, wiping out all recollection of them”
Jehovah doesn’t smite his people as he smites their smiters, nor does he slay them as he slays their slayers
Jehovah flings his people’s enemies far away by his fierce and burning blasts
No hope for the rest of humanity,

Universal Salvation.desc: [Song of Salvation 1] calamity upon the inhabitants of the earth
[Song of Salvation 2] cataclysm on the earth and in the heavens
[Song of Salvation 3] the abolition of death
[Song of Salvation 4] the destruction of Moab
[Song of Salvation 5] punishment of the earth’s inhabitants and of Leviathan

[Universality] The five songs’ contexts suggest that salvation for Jehovah’s people, like the distress that precedes it, occurs universally: the saved remnant hails from “across the sea,” from “the regions of sunrise,” from “the isles of the sea”
...from among all nations and peoples, and from throughout the earth
[Accession] the presence of righteousness in a land where Jehovah’s glory dwells
[Deliverance] Jehovah’s salvation of his people
[Punishment] and the destruction of their enemies
Those whom Jehovah saves are righteous because they follow the straight “path” or “passage” (’orah) of his ordinances
and seek Jehovah day and night
Their salvation “enlarges” or “adds to” (ysp) the nation of Jehovah’s people and transcends earthly boundaries
Those whom Jehovah destroys, on the other hand, are described as “wicked” (rasa‘) and “dead” (metim)
They refuse to learn righteousness, even when an exemplar of righteousness dwells among them
Universal Salvation.details: The larger context of the above passage contains a unique example of Isaiah’s Zion ideology. Among its three common elements, the text cites righteousness (covenantal compliance) and unrighteousness (covenantal rebellion), respectively, as criteria for salvation or destruction.

Universal Salvation.desc: Another passage describes those whom Jehovah gleans from among the nations as “these/they” (hemma) who shout for joy and give glory to Jehovah, the God of Israel, when his “vintage” or judgment of the earth has ended
In that context appears the statement, “From a sector of the earth we hear singing: ‘Glory to the righteous/righteous one!’” (sebi lassaddiq)
The juxtaposition of the pronouns “we” and “they” (hose at home and those abroad) in this passage implies that some who are abroad in the earth have converted to the God of Israel.

The remainder of the passage bears out this conclusion, as those in the category of we (now personified in first person singular) express surprise at the salvation of others: “Whereas I thought, ‘I am wasting away, I am weakening. Woe is me! The traitors have been treacherous, the turncoats have deceitfully betrayed’”
Those whom the text identifies as we (a local entity of Jehovah’s people)
anticipate nothing but treachery from the nations of the earth, from among whom they are gleaned
The term “righteous” or “righteous one” (saddiq) denotes, rhetorically, both Jehovah’s ideal vassal
who serves as an exemplar and paradigm of Jehovah’s people—and a righteous remnant of Jehovah’s people
the antithesis of the “traitors” who betray them
A final passage describes a “nation of the righteous” or a “nation of the righteous one” (goy saddiq)
It keeps faith and trusts in Jehovah through a time of trial, as mentioned.
It enters the gates that Jehovah’s people already within the city open for it
Universal Salvation.details: This further example of those at home and those abroad who experience Jehovah’s salvation forms a part of yet another instance of Isaiah’s Zion ideology in which the term saddiq represents Jehovah’s ideal vassal. As in other instances of this pattern in the first unit, salvation occurs not only because Jehovah’s people or the inhabitants of the earth practice righteousness but because Jehovah’s ideal vassal, a proxy savior of his people, personally occasions Jehovah’s salvation. This latter dimension of salvation—the role the ideal vassal fulfills—gains significance in the second unit.
